column6: to enter or to board a vehicle
column7: To get in is used for cars; to get on is used for all other forms of transportation.
column8: It's easiest to get in the car from the driver's side. The door on the other side doesn't work well. I always get on the bus to work at 34th Street.

column5: to get out of/to get off
column6: to leave or to descend from a vehicle
column7: To get out of is used for cars; to get off is used for all other forms of transportation.
column8: Why don't we stop and get out of the car for a while? Helen got off the train at the 42nd Street terminal.

column6: to place on oneself (usually said of clothes) (S)
column8: Mary put on her coat and left the room.  Put your hat on before you leave the house.

column6: to remove (usually said of clothes) (S)
column8: John took off his jacket as he entered the office.  Take your sweater off. The room is very warm.

column6: to telephone (also: to give someone a call) (S)
column7: To call can be used instead of to call up, as in the first example below.
column8: I forgot to call up Mr. Jones yesterday. I'd better call him now.  Call me up tomorrow, Jane. We'll arrange a time to have lunch together. I promise to give you a call as soon as I arrive in New York.

column6: to start or cause to function (also: to switch on) (S)
column8: Please turn on the light; it's too dark in here. Do you know who turned the air conditioning on?

column6: to cause to stop functioning (also: to switch off, to shut off) (S)
column7: Turn on and turn off, as well as their related forms, are used for things that flow, such as electricity, water, gas, etc.
column8: Please turn off the light when you leave the room. Are you really listening to the radio, or should I turn it off?

column6: very soon; immediately (also: at once)
column8: Dad says that dinner will be ready right away, so we'd better wash our hands and set the table. Tell Will to come to my office right away. I must see him immediately. Stop playing that loud music at once!

column6: to lift from the floor, table, etc., with one's fingers (S)
column8: Harry picked up the newspaper that was on the front doorstep. Could you pick your toy up before someone falls over it?

column6: eventually, after a period of time
column8: If you study English seriously, sooner or later you'll become fluent. I'm too tired to do my homework now; I'm sure I'll do it sooner or later.

column6: to arise, to rise from a bed; to make someone arise (S)
column7: For the last definition a noun phrase must separate the verb and particle.
column8: Carla gets up at seven o'clock every morning. At what time should we get the children up tomorrow?

column6: in the beginning, originally
column8: At first English was difficult for him, but later he made great progress. I thought at first that it was Sheila calling, but then I realized that it was Betty.

column6: to wear formal clothes, to dress very nicely
column8: We should definitely dress up to go to the theater. You don't have to dress up for Mike's party.

column6: finally, after a long time
column8: We waited for hours and then the train arrived at last. Now that I am sixteen, at last I can drive my parents' car.

column6: as is the general case, as is typical
column8: George is late for class as usual. This seems to happen every day.  As usual, Dora received first prize in the swimming contest. It's the third consecutive year that she has won.

column6: get information about, to determine (S)
column7: This idiom is separable only when a pronoun is used, as in the second example.
column8: Will you please try to find out what time the airplane arrives? I'll call right now to find it out.

column6: give one's attention to; to watch
column8: The teacher told us to look at the blackboard and not at our books. I like to walk along a country road at night and look at the stars.

column6: to try to find, to search for
column7: An adverb phrase such as all over can be put between the verb and preposition, as in the second example, however, the idiom cannot be separated by a noun or pronoun.
column8: He's spent over an hour looking for the pen that he lost. So there you are! We've looked all over for you.

column6: acceptable, fine; yes, okay
column7: This idiom can also be spelled alright in informal usage.
column8: He said that it would be all right to wait in her office until she returned. Do you want me to turn off the TV? Alright, if you insist.

column6: all the time, from the beginning (without change)
column8: She knew all along that we'd never agree with his plan. You're smiling! Did you know all along that I'd give you a birthday present?

column6: gradually, slowly (also: step by step)
column8: Karen's health seems to be improving little by little. If you study regularly each day, step by step your vocabulary will increase.

column6: to make very weary due to difficult conditions or hard effort (also: to wear out) (S)
column8: The hot weather tired out the runners in the marathon. Does studying for final exams wear you out? It makes me feel worn out!

column6: to ask for a response from; to visit (also: to drop in on)
column8: Jose didn't know the answer when the teacher called on him. Last night several friends called on us at our home. Why don't we drop in on Sally a little later?

column6: don't be concerned about it; ignore what was just said
column8: When he spilled his drink on my coat, I said, "Never mind. It needs to be cleaned anyway." So you weren't listening to me again. Never mind; it wasn't important.

column6: to choose, to select (S)
column8: Ann picked out a good book to give to her brother as a graduation gift. Johnny, if you want me to buy you a toy, then pick one out now.

column5: to take one's (my, his, your, etc.) time
column6: to do without rush, not to hurry
column7: This idiom is often used in the imperative form. (See the first example)
column8: There's no need to hurry doing those exercises. Take your time. William never works rapidly. He always takes his time in everything that he does.

column6: to discuss or consider a situation with others (S)
column8: We talked over Carla's plan to install an air conditioner in the room, but we couldn't reach a decision. Before I accepted the new job offer, I talked the matter over with my wife.

column6: to place oneself in a flat position, to recline
column8: If you are tired, why don't you lie down for an hour or so? The doctor says that Grace must lie down and rest for a short time every afternoon.

column6: to rise from a sitting or lying position (also: to get up)
column8: When the president entered the room, everyone stood up. Suzy, stop rolling around on the floor; get up now.

column6: to be seated (also: to take a seat)
column8: We sat down on the park bench and watched the children play. There aren't any more chairs, but you can take a seat on the floor.

column6: the entire day, week, month, year
column8: I've been working on my income tax forms all day long. I've hardly had time to eat. It's been raining all week long. We haven't seen the sun since last Monday.

column6: alone, without assistance
column8: Francis translated that French novel by himself. No one helped him. Paula likes to walk through the woods by herself, but her brother prefers to walk with a companion.

column6: for a reason, deliberately
column7: This idiom is usually used when someone does something wrong or unfair.
column8: Do you think that she didn't come to the meeting on purpose? It was no accident that he broke my glasses. He did it on purpose.

column6: to associate or work well with; to succeed or manage in doing (also: to get on with someone or something)
column8: Terry isn't getting along with her new roommate; they argue constantly. How are you getting on with your studies?

column6: to be of importance (to), to affect
column7: This idiom is often used with adjectives to show the degree of importance.
column8: It makes a big difference to me whether he likes the food I serve. Does it make any difference to you where we go for dinner? No, it doesn't make any difference. It makes no difference to Lisa either.

column6: to remove, to extract (S); to go on a date with (S) (also: to go out with)
column8: Students, take out your books and open them to page twelve. Did you take Sue out last night? No, she couldn't go out with me.

column6: to be involved in, to participate in (also: to be in on)
column8: Martin was sick and could not take part in the meeting yesterday. I didn't want to be in on their argument, so I remained silent.

column6: to any degree (also: in the least)
column7: This idiom is used with the negative to add emphasis to a statement.
column8: Larry isn't at all shy about expressing his opinions. When I asked Donna whether she was tired, she said, "Not in the least. I'm full of energy."

column6: to locate information in a directory, dictionary, book, etc. (S)
column8: Ellen suggested that we look up Lee's telephone number in the directory. Students should try to understand the meaning of a new word from context before looking the word up in the dictionary.

column6: to serve in a store or restaurant
column8: A very pleasant young clerk waited on me in that shop. The restaurant waitress asked us, "Has anyone waited on you yet?"

column6: a minimum of, no fewer (or less) than
column8: I spend at least two hours every night on my studies. Mike claims that he drinks at least a quart of water every day.

column6: until now, until the present time (also: up to now, as of yet)
column7: This idiom is usually used with the present perfect tense.
column8: So far, this year has been excellent for business. I hope that the good luck continues. How many idioms have we studied in this book up to now?  As of yet, we have not had an answer from him.

column5: to take a walk, stroll, hike, etc.
column6: to go for a walk, stroll, hike, etc.
column7: A stroll involves slow, easy walking; a hike involves serious, strenuous walking.
column8: Last evening we took a walk around the park. It's a fine day. Would you like to take a stroll along Mason Boulevard? Let's take a hike up Cowles Mountain this afternoon.

column6: to go on a journey, to travel
column8: I'm so busy at work that I have no time to take a trip. During the summer holidays, the Thompsons took a trip to Europe.

column6: to wear clothes to check the style or fit before buying (S)
column8: He tried on several suits before he picked out a blue one. Why don't you try these shoes on next?

column6: to consider carefully before deciding (S)
column8: I'd like to think over your offer first. Then can we talk it over tomorrow? You don't have to give me your decision now. Think it over for a while.

column6: to occur, to happen according to plan
column8: The regular meetings of the committee take place in Constitution Hall. I thought that the celebration was taking place at John's house.

column6: to remove from sight, to put in the proper place (S)
column8: Please put away your papers before you open the test booklet. John put the notepad away in his desk when he was finished with it.

column6: to be careful or cautious (also: to watch out)
column7: Both of these idioms can occur with the preposition for.
column8: "Look out!" Jeffrey cried as his friend almost stepped in a big hole in the ground.  Look out for reckless drivers whenever you cross the street. Small children should always watch out for strangers offering candy.

column6: to exchange greetings by clasping hands
column8: When people meet for the first time, they usually shake hands. The student warmly shook hands with his old professor.

column6: to return (S)
column8: Mr. Harris got back from his business trip to Chicago this morning. Could you get the children back home by five o'clock?

column6: to become sick with a cold of the nose or throat
column8: If you go out in the rain, you will surely catch cold. How did she ever catch cold in such warm weather?

column6: to recover from an illness; to accept a loss or sorrow
column8: It took me over a month to get over my cold, but I'm finally well now. It seems that Mr. Mason will never get over the death of his wife.

column5: to make up one's (my, his, your, etc.) mind
column6: to reach a decision, to decide finally
column8: Sally is considering several colleges to attend, but she hasn't made up her mind yet. When are you going to make up your mind about your vacation plans?

column5: to change one's (my, his, your, etc.) mind
column6: to alter one's decision or opinion
column8: We have changed our minds and are going to Canada instead of California this summer. Matthew has changed his mind several times about buying a new car.

column6: temporarily (also: for now)
column8: For the time being, Janet is working as a waitress, but she really hopes to become an actress soon. We're living in an apartment for now, but soon we'll be looking for a house to buy.

column6: permanently, forever
column8: Ruth has returned to Canada for good. She won't ever live in the United States again. Are you finished with school for good, or will you continue your studies some day?

column6: to cancel (S)
column8: The referee called off the soccer game because of the darkness. The president called the meeting off because she had to leave town.

column6: to postpone (S)
column8: Many students put off doing their assignments until the last minute. Let's put the party off until next weekend, okay?

column6: hurried, rushed (also: in a rush)
column8: Alex seems in a hurry; he must be late for his train again. She's always in a rush in the morning to get the kids to school.

column6: not feeling well, sick
column8: John stayed home from work because he was feeling under the weather. When you catch cold, you feel under the weather.

column6: to place clothes on a hook or hanger (S); to replace the receiver on the phone at the end of a conversation (S)
column8: Would you like me to hang up your coat for you in the closet? The operator told me to hang the phone up and call the number again.

column6: to trust someone in time of need (also: to depend on)
column8: I can count on my parents to help me in an emergency. Don't depend on Frank to lend you any money; he doesn't have any.

column6: to become friendly with others
column8: Patricia is a shy girl and doesn't make friends easily. During the cruise Ronald made friends with almost everyone on the ship.

column6: not in working condition
column8: The elevator was out of order, so we had to walk to the tenth floor of the building. We couldn't use the soft drink machine because it was out of order.

column6: to be able to do something special; to arrive at a place, such as home, work, etc.
column7: For the second definition, do not use the preposition to with the words home or there.
column8: The children got to stay up late and watch a good movie for the family. I missed the bus and couldn't get to the office until ten o'clock. When are you planning to get home tonight?

column6: not frequent, unusual, rare
column8: The times that our children get to stay up late are few and far between. Airplane travel is very safe because accidents are few and far between.

column6: to examine, to inspect closely (also: to go over, to read over, to check over) (S)
column7: Go over is different from the other forms because it is not separable.
column8: I want to look my homework over again before I give it to the teacher. The politician went over his speech before the important presentation. You should never sign any legal paper without checking it over first.

column6: to have free time, not to have to work (also: to take time off (S))
column7: The related form (S)  to take time off is used when someone makes a decision to have free time, sometimes when others might not agree with the decision.
column8: Every morning the company workers have time off for a coffee break. Several workers took the afternoon off to go to a baseball game.

column6: to happen; to resume, to continue (also: to keep on)
column8: Many people gathered near the accident to see what was going on. I didn't mean to interrupt you. Please go on. The speaker kept on talking even though most of the audience had left.

column6: extinguish, to cause to stop functioning (S)
column7: To put out has the same meaning as to turn off (Lesson 1) for a light fixture.
column8: No smoking is allowed in here. Please put out your cigarette. The fire fighters worked hard to put the brush fire out. Please put out the light before you leave. Okay, I'll put it out.

column6: suddenly, without warning (also: all at once)
column8: All of a sudden Ed appeared at the door. We weren't expecting him to drop by.  All at once Millie got up and left the house without any explanation.

column6: to show, to indicate, to bring to one's attention (S)
column8: What important buildings did the tour guide point out to you? The teacher pointed out the mistakes in my composition. A friend pointed the famous actor out to me.

column6: to expire, to be finished
column7: This idiom is used only with the word time as the subject.
column8: "The time is up," the teacher said at the end of the test period. We have to leave the tennis court because our hour is up; some other people want to use it now.

column6: to be finished, to end (also: to be through)
column7: This idiom is used for activities and events.
column8: After the dance was over, we all went to a restaurant. The meeting was through ten minutes earlier than everyone expected.

column6: exactly at the correct time, punctually
column8: I thought that Margaret would arrive late, but she was right on time. Did you get to work on time this morning, or did rush hour traffic delay you?

column6: before the time necessary to do something
column8: We entered the theater just in time to see the beginning of the movie. The truck was not able to stop in time to prevent an accident.

column6: to become better, worse, etc.
column8: Heather has been sick for a month, but now she is getting better. This medicine isn't helping me. Instead of getting better, I'm getting worse.

column5: to get sick (well, tired, busy, wet, etc.)
column6: to become sick, well, tired, busy, wet, etc.
column7: This idiom consists of a combination of get and various adjectives.
column8: Gerald got sick last week and has been in bed since that time. Every afternoon I get very hungry, so I eat a snack.

column6: should, ought to, be advisable to
column7: This idiom is most often used in contracted form (I'd better).
column8: I think you'd better speak to Mr. White right away about this matter. The doctor told the patient that he'd better go home and rest.

column6: prefer to (also: would just as soon (do something) as (do something else))
column8: Would you rather have the appointment this Friday or next Monday? I would just as soon go for a walk as watch TV right now.

column6: to stop working for the rest of the day/night
column8: Herb tried to repair his car engine all morning before he called it a day and went fishing. We've been working hard on this project all evening; let's call it a night.

column6: to solve, to find a solution (S); to understand (S)
column8: How long did it take you to figure out the answer to the math problem? I was never able to figure it out.

column6: to have a (good or bad) opinion of
column7: This idiom is often used in the negative or with adjectives such as much and highly.
column8: I don't think much of him as a baseball player; he's a slow runner and a poor hitter. James thinks highly of his new boss, who is a kind and helpful person.

column5: to be about to do something
column6: to be at the moment of doing something, to be ready
column7: This idiom is often used with the adverb just.
column8: I was just about to leave when you telephoned. Oh, hi, John. We're just about to eat dinner.

column6: to move or face in the opposite direction (S); to completely change the condition of (S)
column8: The man turned his car around and drove back the way he came. The company has been very successful since the new business manager was able to turn it around.

column6: to alternate, to change people while doing something
column8: During the trip, Darlene and I took turns driving so that neither of us would tire out. I have to make sure that my two sons take turns playing the video game.

column6: to look at and listen to someone while they are speaking, to concentrate
column8: Please pay attention to me while I'm speaking to you! You'll have to pay more attention in class if you want to get a good grade.

column6: to review something in order to refresh one's memory
column8: Before I traveled to Mexico, I brushed up on my Spanish; I haven't practiced it since high school. In order to take that advanced mathematics class, Sidney will have to brush up on his algebra.

column6: repeatedly (also: time after time, time and again)
column8: The actress studied her lines in the movie over and over until she knew them well. Children have difficulty remembering rules, so it's often necessary to repeat them over and over again. Time and again I have to remind Bobby to put on his seatbelt in the car.

column6: to use something until it has no value or worth anymore, to make useless through wear (S)
column8: When I wear out these shoes, I'll have to buy some that last longer. What do you do with your clothes after you wear them out?

column6: to discard, to dispose of (S)
column8: I generally throw away my clothes when I wear them out. Don't throw the magazines away; I haven't read them yet.

column6: to begin to love
column7: This idiom is used with the expression at first sight to indicate a sudden interest in love.
column8: Ben and Sal fell in love in high school, and got married after graduation. Have you ever fallen in love at first sight?

column6: to stop functioning; to stop burning; to leave home or work (also: to step out)
column8: The lights went out all over the city because of an electrical problem. The campers didn't have to put out the fire because it went out by itself. Gary isn't here right now; he went out to the store for a moment. I have to step out of the office briefly to pick up a newspaper.

column6: impossible, not feasible
column8: Stephen told Deborah that it was out of the question for her to borrow his new car. Don't expect me to do that again. It's absolutely out of the question.

column6: to have some connection with or relationship to
column8: Ralph insisted that he had nothing to do with breaking the window. What does your suggestion have to do with our problem?

column6: to arise from sleep, to awaken (S)
column7: Compare wake up and get up (Lesson 1) as used in the first example.
column8: Marge woke up this morning very early, but she did not get up until about ten o'clock. My alarm clock wakes me up at the same time every day.

column6: to manage, to have responsibility for
column8: Jane is in charge of the office while Mrs. Haig is on a business trip. Who is in charge of arrangements for the dance next week?

column6: just after, when
column8: As soon as it started to snow, the children ran outside with big smiles on their faces. I'm busy now, but I'll meet you as soon as I've finished this work.

column6: to communicate with, to contact
column8: You can get in touch with him by calling the Burma Hotel. I've been trying all morning to get in touch with Miss Peters, but her phone is always busy.

column6: to enjoy oneself
column8: We all had a good time at the class reunion last night. Did you have a good time at the park? I really enjoyed it.

column6: very quickly, rapidly
column7: This idiom can be used with the idiom at all to add emphasis to the certainty of the statement.
column8: Mac said that he'd be ready to leave in no time. We thought that the meeting would take two hours, but it was over in no time at all.

column6: to reduce, to lessen (also: to cut back on)
column8: In order to lose weight, you have to cut down on your intake of sugar. The doctor told me to cut back on exercise until my back injury heals.

column6: many
column8: Quite a few students were absent yesterday; in fact, more than half of them were not there. We did not expect many people to attend the affair, but quite a few of our friends actually came.

column6: formerly did, had the habit of
column7: This idiom is used to indicate a past situation, action, or habit that does not exist in the present. The idiom is always followed by a simple verb form.
column8: I used to live in New York, but I moved to California two years ago. Kim used to smoke cigarettes, but she stopped the habit last month.

column6: be accustomed to
column7: This idiom refers to a situation, action, or habit that continues in the present. The idiom is always followed by a noun or gerund phrase.
column8: He is used to this climate now, so the changes in temperature do not affect him much. I am used to studying in the library, so it's difficult for me to study at home now.

column6: to become used to, to become adjusted to
column7: This idiom describes the process of change that allows someone to be used to a situation, action, or habit.
column8: It took Yoshiko a long time to get used to the food that her American host family served her. Mark can't seem to get used to wearing contact lenses; recently he's been wearing his glasses a lot.

column6: in a backward and forward motion
column8: The restless lion kept pacing back and forth along the front of its cage. Grandmother finds it relaxing to sit in her rocking chair and move back and forth.

column6: to be sure, to ascertain (also: to make certain (of))
column8: Please make sure that you turn off the radio before you go out. Could you make certain of the time? I don't want to miss that TV show.

column6: occasionally, sometimes (also: now and again, at times, from time to time, off and on, once in a while)
column7: Both now and then and once in a while can be preceded by the adjective every. Another idiom with the same meaning and form is every so often.
column8: I don't see him very often, but (every) now and then we arrange to have lunch together. Gary gets a cold (every) once in a while even though he takes good care of himself. Every so often my brother and I get together for a camping trip. I like to sleep late in the morning from time to time.

column6: to eliminate, to remove; to discard, to throw away
column8: Jerry tried hard to get rid of the stain on his shirt, but he never succeeded. The stain was so bad that Jerry finally had to get rid of his shirt.

column6: every second (one), alternate (ones)
column8: I play tennis with my father every other Saturday, so I usually play twice a month. There were twenty problems in the exercise, but the teacher told us only to do every other one. Actually, doing ten problems was difficult enough.

column6: to match, to compare well in color or design; to date, to accompany (also: to go out with)
column7: For the first definition, adverbs such as well and poorly are often used.
column8: That striped shirt goes well with the gray pants, but the pants go poorly with those leather shoes. Eda went with Richard for about six months, but now she is going out with a new boyfriend.

column6: excellent, superb
column8: The food served in that four-star restaurant is truly first-rate. The Beverly Hills Hotel provides first-rate service to its guests.

column6: to originate from
column7: This idiom is commonly used in discussion of one's home town, state, or country.
column8: What country in South America does she come from? She comes from Peru. I just learned that he really comes from Florida, not Texas. Where did this package come from? The mail carrier brought it.

column6: to travel a sufficient distance at a reasonable speed
column7: The adjective excellent can also be used.
column8: On our last trip, it rained the entire time, so we didn't make good time. We made excellent time on our trip to Florida; it only took eighteen hours.

column6: to stir or shake well (S); to confuse, to bewilder (S)
column7: For the second definition, the passive forms to be mixed up or to get mixed up are often used.
column8: You should mix up the ingredients well before you put them in the pan. The teacher's poor explanation really mixed the students up. The students think it's their fault that they are mixed up so often.

column6: to give attention or time to (also: to attend to, to see to)
column8: Who is going to see about getting us a larger room for the meeting? I'll see to arranging music for the wedding if you attend to the entertainment.

column6: to do, to succeed, to progress
column8: Charlie didn't make out very well on his final examinations. He may have to repeat one or more classes. How did Rachelle make out on her acting audition in Hollywood yesterday?

column6: by memorizing
column8: He knows many passages from Shakespeare by heart. Do you know all the idioms you have studied in this book by heart?

column6: not to enter, not allow to enter (S)
column8: There was a large sign outside the door that said, "Danger! Keep out!" I've told you to keep the dog out of the house.

column6: to stay at a distance (from) (S); to avoid use of (also: stay away from)
column8: Please be sure to keep the children away from the street! The signs on the burned-out house said, "Keep Away! Danger Zone." It's important for your health to stay away from dangerous drugs.

column6: to criticize, to complain about something
column8: It is very easy to find fault with the work of others, but more difficult to accept criticism of one's own work. Mrs. Johnson is always finding fault with her children, but they really try to please their mother.

column6: to be responsible for deciding; to be doing as a regular activity
column7: The second definition is most often used in a question as a form of greeting.
column8: I don't care whether we go to the reception or not. It's up to you. Hi, George. I haven't seen you in a while. What have you been up to?

column6: uncomfortable or worried in a situation
column8: Speaking in front of a large audience makes many people feel ill at ease. My wife and I were ill at ease because our daughter was late coming home from a date.

column6: to revise, to do again (S)
column7: A noun or pronoun must separate the two parts of this idiom.
column8: You'd better do the letter over because it is written so poorly. Jose made so many mistakes in his homework that the teacher made him do it over.

column6: to investigate, to examine carefully (also: to check into)
column8: The police are looking into the matter of the stolen computers. The congressional committee will check into the financial dealings of the government contractor.

column6: to grasp, to grip with the hands
column8: You should take hold of the railing as you go down those steep stairs. The blind man took hold of my arm as I led him across the street.

column5: to get through doing something, to get through with something
column6: to finish, to complete
column7: This idiom is followed either by the -ing form of a verb (a gerund) or by the preposition with.
column8: I didn't get through studying last night until almost eleven o'clock. At what time does your wife get through with work every day?

column6: from this time into the future
column8: Mr. Lee's doctor told him to cut down on eating fatty foods from now on, or else he might suffer heart disease. I'm sorry that I dropped by at a bad time. From now on I'll call you first.

column6: to keep or maintain a record of; to remember the location of
column8: Steve keeps track of all the long-distance telephone calls related to his business that he makes from his home. With seven small children, how do the Wilsons keep track of all of them?

column6: to be greatly affected by a strong feeling (S)
column7: This idiom can also be used with get instead of be.
column8: Paula and Leanne were carried away by the sad movie that they saw together. James got carried away with anger when his roommate crashed his new car into a telephone pole.

column6: modern, current, timely
column7: Hyphens (-) separate the parts of this idiom when it precedes a noun form, as in the third example. The verb to update derives from this idiom.
column8: The president insisted that the company bring its aging equipment up to date. This catalog is not up to date. It was published several years ago. The news program gave an up-to-date account of the nuclear accident. The newscaster said that he would update the news report every half hour.

column6: not modern, not current, not timely; no longer available in published form
column7: Again, hyphens separate the parts of this idiom when it precedes a noun form as in the second example. The passive verb to be outdated derives from this idiom.
column8: Many people buy new cars when their old cars become out of date. I don't know why Gene likes to wear out-of-date clothing. His clothes are so outdated that even his girlfriend hesitates to be seen with him. This book can't be ordered any more because it is out of date.

column6: to inflate, to fill with air (S); to explode, to destroy (or be destroyed) by explosion (S)
column8: Daddy, could you please blow up this balloon for me? When the airplane crashed into the ground, it blew up immediately. The military had to blow the missile up in midair when it started to go the wrong way.

column6: to begin to burn
column8: Don't stand too close to the gas stove. Your clothes may catch fire. No one seems to know how the old building caught fire.

column6: to burn slowly, but completely (usually said of candles); to destroy completely by fire (S)
column8: There was a large amount of wax on the table where the candles had burned down. The fire spread so quickly that the firefighters could not prevent the whole block of buildings from burning down.

column6: to destroy completely by fire (S); to make angry or very annoyed (S) (also to tick off)
column7: To burn up and to burn down (previous idiom) share the same definition but also have different definitions.
column8: She didn't want anyone to see the letter, so she burned it up and threw the ashes away. It really burns me up that he borrowed my car without asking me first. Mike got ticked off that his friends never offered to help him move to his new apartment. He had to do everything himself.

column6: to stop functioning because of overuse; to make tired from too much work (S)
column8: This light bulb has burned out. Could you get another one? Studying all day for my final exams has really burned me out.

column6: to succeed
column8: He is a hard worker, and I'm sure that he will make good in that new job. Alma has always made good in everything that she has done.

column6: to be clear and logical
column7: This idiom is almost always used with the pronoun subject it and is followed by a that clause.
column8: It stands to reason that a person without experience cannot do the work as well as an experienced one. It stands to reason that he isn't going to pass the course if he never studies.

column6: to become widespread suddenly
column8: An epidemic of measles broke out in Chicago this past week. If a nuclear war ever breaks out, it is unlikely that many people will survive. The news says that a large fire has broken out in a huge chemical plant.

column6: regarding, concerning (also: as to)
column8: As for the money, we will simply have to borrow some more from the bank. There is no doubt as to her intelligence; she's the smartest one in the class.

column6: to pity, to feel compassion for (also: to take pity on)
column8: Don't you feel sorry for someone who has to work the night shift? I helped drive Pierre around when he broke his foot because I took pity on him.

column6: to stop functioning
column7: Compare this idiom with to burn out in Lesson 12. To burn out means that electrical equipment becomes hot from overuse and stops functioning. To break down means that something stops functioning mechanically, whether from overuse or not.
column8: I just bought my new car yesterday and already it has broken down. The elevator broke down, so we walked all the way up to the top floor.

column6: to become or result; to appear, to attend (also: to come out)
column7: The noun form turnout derives from the second definition of the idiom.
column8: Most parents wonder how their children will turn out as adults. Hundreds of people came out for the demonstration against new taxes. What was the turnout for the public hearing on the education reforms?

column6: rarely, infrequently
column8: Snow falls on the city of San Diego, California, once in a blue moon. Once in a blue moon my wife and I eat at a very expensive restaurant.

column6: to stop trying; to stop a bad habit (S); to surrender (S)
column8: I'm sure that you can accomplish this task. Don't give up yet! If you give up smoking now, you can certainly live a longer life. The soldiers gave themselves up in the face of stronger enemy forces.

column6: to cancel by marking with a horizontal line (S)
column8: The teacher crossed out several incorrect words in Tanya's composition. I crossed the last line out of my letter because it had the wrong tone to it.

column6: not to appreciate fully (S); to assume to be true without giving much thought (S)
column7: A noun or pronoun often follows the verb take.
column8: John took his wife for granted until once when he was very sick and needed her constant attention for a week. He spoke English so well that I took it for granted he was an American. He took for granted that I wasn't American because I spoke English so poorly!

column6: to consider a fact while evaluating a situation (S)
column7: Again, a noun or pronoun often follows the verb take.
column8: The judge took the prisoner's young age into account before sentencing him to three months in jail. Educators should take into account the cultural backgrounds of students when planning a school curriculum.

column6: to clarify, to explain (S)
column8: Please make clear that he should never act so impolitely again. The supervisor made it clear to the workers that they had to increase their productivity.

column6: clearly stated, definite, apparent
column8: The president's message was clear-cut: the company had to reduce personnel immediately. Professor Larsen is well known for his interesting and clear-cut presentations.

column6: to be wearing (S)
column8: How do you like the hat which Grace has on today? When Sally came into the room, I had nothing on except my shorts.

column6: to regain consciousness; to equal, to amount to
column8: At first they thought that the man was dead, but soon he came to. The bill for groceries at the supermarket came to fifty dollars.

column6: to require; to request, to urge
column8: This cake recipe calls for some baking soda, but we don't have any. The members of Congress called for new laws to regulate the banking industry.

column6: to eat at home/to eat in a restaurant
column8: I feel too tired to go out for dinner. Let's eat in again tonight. When you eat out, what restaurant do you generally go to?

column6: predictable, known beforehand; boring
column8: The results of the national election were rather cut and dried; the Republicans won easily. A job on a factory assembly line is certainly cut and dried.

column6: to watch, to supervise, to protect (also: to take care of, to keep an eye on)
column8: Grandma will look after the baby while we go to the lecture. Who is going to take care of your house plants while you are away? I'd appreciate it if you'd keep an eye on my car while I'm in the store.

column6: to have the desire to, to want to consider
column7: This idiom is usually followed by a gerund (the -ing form of a verb used as a noun).
column8: I don't feel like studying tonight. Let's go to a basketball game. I feel like taking a long walk. Would you like to go with me?

column6: finally, absolutely
column8: My daughter told her boyfriend once and for all that she wouldn't date him anymore. Once and for all, John has quit smoking cigarettes.

column6: to receive news or information from
column7: To hear from is used for receiving a letter, telephone call, etc., from a person or organization.
column8: I don't hear from my brother very often since he moved to Chicago. Have you heard from the company about that new job?

column6: to know about, to be familiar with; to consider
column7: The second definition is always used in the negative.
column8: When I asked for directions to Mill Street, the police officer said that she had never heard of it. Byron strongly disagreed with my request by saying, "I won't hear of it!"

column6: to laugh at, to joke about
column8: They are making fun of Carla's new hair style. Don't you think that it's really strange? Don't make fun of Jose's English. He's doing the best he can.

column6: to become reality, to prove to be correct
column8: The weatherman's forecast for today's weather certainly came true. Everything that the economists predicted about the increased cost of living has come true.

column6: really, actually (also: in fact)
column8: Hans thinks he knows English well but, as a matter of fact, he speaks very poorly. I didn't say that. In fact, I said quite the opposite.

column6: to arrange matters the way one wants (especially when someone else doesn't want the same way) (also: to get one's way)
column8: My brother always wants to have his way, but this time our parents said that we could do what I wanted. If Sheila doesn't get her way, she becomes very angry.

column6: to expect or anticipate with pleasure
column7: This idiom can be followed by a regular noun or a gerund.
column8: We're greatly looking forward to our vacation in Mexico. Margaret never looks forward to going to work.

column6: with the inside facing the outside
column8: Someone should tell little Bobby that his shirt is inside out. The high winds ruined the umbrella by blowing it inside out.

column6: with the upper side turned toward the lower side
column8: The accident caused one car to turn upside down, its wheels spinning in the air. One of the students was only pretending to read her textbook; the teacher could see that the book was actually upside down.

column6: to write answers in (S); to inform, to tell (S)
column7: For the second definition, the idiom can be followed by the preposition on and the information that someone is told.
column8: You should be careful to fill in the blanks on the registration form correctly. Barry was absent from the meeting, so I'd better fill him in. Has anyone filled the boss in on the latest public relations disaster?

column6: to complete a form (S)
column7: This idiom is very similar to the first definition above. To fill in refers to completing various parts of a form, while to fill out refers to completing a form as one whole item.
column8: Every prospective employee must fill out an application by giving name, address, previous jobs, etc. The teenager had some trouble filling the forms out by himself, so his mother helped him.

column6: to use well, to profit from; to use another person's weaknesses to gain what one wants
column8: I took advantage of my neighbor's superior skill at tennis to improve my own ability at the game. Teddy is such a small, weak child that his friends take advantage of him all the time. They take advantage of him by demanding money and making him do things for them.

column6: regardless of
column7: This idiom is a shortened form of it doesn't matter. It is followed by a question word such as how, where, when, who, etc.
column8: No matter how much money he spends on his clothes, he never looks well dressed. No matter where that escaped prisoner tries to hide, the police will find him sooner or later.

column6: to begin to do or study, to undertake (S); to occupy space, time, or energy (S)
column8: After today's exam, the class will be ready to take up the last chapter in the book. The piano takes up too much space in our living room. However, it would take too much time up to move it right now; so we'd better wait until later.

column6: to consult someone about an important matter (S)
column7: The important matter follows the verb take, while the person consulted follows with.
column8: Can I take the problem up with you right now? It's quite urgent. I can't help you with this matter. You'll have to take it up with the manager.

column6: to resemble a parent or close relative (for physical appearance only, also: to look like)
column8: Which of your parents do you take after the most? Sam looks like his father, but he takes after his mother in personality.

column6: eventually, after a long period of time
column7: This idiom is similar in meaning to sooner or later (Lesson 1). The difference is that in the long run refers to a more extended period of time.
column8: In the long run, the synthetic weave in this carpet will wear better than the woolen one. You won't have to replace it so soon. If you work hard at your marriage, you'll find out that, in the long run, your spouse can be your best friend in life.

column6: having contact
column8: James will be in touch with us soon to relay the details of the plan. I certainly enjoyed seeing you again after all these years. Let's be sure to keep in touch.

column6: not having contact; not having knowledge of
column8: Marge and I had been out of touch for years, but then suddenly she called me up the other day. Larry has been so busy that he seems out of touch with world events.

column6: alert, cautious
column7: This idiom is usually used with the verbs stay and keep.
column8: It's important for all the players on a soccer team to stay on their toes. We'd better keep on our toes while we're walking along the dark portions of this street.

column6: to make progress; to manage to live in a certain state of health
column8: Juan is getting along very well in his English studies. How is Mr. Richards getting along after his long illness?

column6: partially deaf, not able to hear well
column8: You'll have to speak a little louder. Mrs. Evans is hard of hearing. Please don't shout. I'm not hard of hearing. Listening to loud music too much can make you hard of hearing.

column5: to see eye to eye (on something/with somebody)
column6: to agree, to concur
column8: I'm glad that we see eye to eye on the matter of the conference location. A husband and wife don't always see eye to eye with each other, but a good marriage can survive small disagreements.

column6: to be considering, to be thinking (S)
column8: I don't want to see a movie now. I have in mind going to the park. It's up to you what we eat tonight. Do you have anything in mind?

column6: to remember, not to forget (S) (also: to bear in mind)
column8: Please keep in mind that you promised to call Stan around noon. I didn't know that Paula doesn't like vegetables. We should bear that in mind next time we invite her for dinner.

column6: this one time, for only one time
column8: For once I was able to win a game of golf against Steve, who is a much better player than I am. Dad, for once would you please let me drive the new car?

column6: to explode, to sound as an alarm; to leave suddenly without explanation
column8: The accident happened when a box of firecrackers went off accidentally. For what time did you set the alarm clock to go off tomorrow morning? Vince went off without saying good-bye to anybody; I hope he wasn't angry.

column6: to outgrow, to become too old for, to be a result of
column8: He still bites his nails now and then, but soon he'll grow out of the habit. The need for the salary committee grew out of worker dissatisfaction with the pay scale.

column6: to do the best that one can in a poor situation
column8: If we can't find a larger apartment soon, we'll just have to make the best of it right here. Even though the Martinez family is having financial problems, they make the best of everything by enjoying the simple pleasures of life.

column6: to shorten by cutting the ends (S); to disconnect or stop suddenly (S)
column8: The rope was two feet longer than we needed, so we cut off the extra length. The operator cut our long-distance phone conversation off after two minutes.

column6: to remove by cutting (S); to stop doing something (S) (for the second definition, also: to knock it off)
column7: For the second definition, the idiom is usually separated by the pronoun it.
column8: The child likes to cut out pictures from the newspaper and to paste them in a notebook. He kept bothering her, so finally she told him to cut it out. However, he wouldn't knock it off until her larger brother appeared.

column6: to explode, to go flat (for tires); to extinguish by blowing (S)
column8: On our trip to Colorado, one of the car tires blew out when it hit a large hole in the road. Little Joey wasn't able to blow all the candles out, so his big sister helped him.

column6: to happen to (a missing object or person)
column7: This idiom is always used in a clause beginning with what.
column8: What has become of my pencil? I had it ten minutes ago, but now I can't find it. I wondered what became of you. I looked around the shopping center for two hours, but I couldn't find you at all.

column6: to close for a period of time (S); to be quiet, to stop talking
column7: The second definition of this idiom is impolite in formal situations.
column8: During the hurricane, all the store owners shut their shops up. Bob's sister told him to shut up and not say anything more about it. The student got into big trouble for telling his teacher to shut up.

column6: to have, to possess
column8: Curtis has got a bad cold. He's sneezing and coughing a lot. How much money have you got with you right now?

column6: must (also: have to)
column8: She has got to go to Chicago today to sign the contract papers. I have to be back home by two o'clock or my wife will feel ill at ease.

column6: to maintain the same speed or rate as
column8: Frieda works so fast that no one in the office can keep up with her. You'll have to walk more slowly. I can't keep up with you.

column6: however, in contrast
column8: Democracies provide people many freedoms and privileges. On the other hand, democracies suffer many serious problems such as crime and unemployment. My sister takes after my father in appearance. On the other hand, I take after my mother.

column6: to reduce in brightness or volume (S); to reject, to refuse (S)
column8: Please turn down the radio for me. It's too loud while I'm studying. Laverne wanted to join the military but the recruiting officer turned her application down because Laverne is hard of hearing in one ear.

column6: divided into two equal parts
column8: Let's go fifty-fifty on the cost of a new rug for our apartment. The political candidate has a fifty-fifty chance of winning the election.

column6: gradually to prepare something for use that is new and stiff (S); to interrupt (for the second definition, also: to cut in)
column8: It is best to break a new car in by driving it slowly for the first few hundred miles. While Carrie and I were talking, Bill broke in to tell me about a telephone call. Peter, it's very impolite to cut in like that while others are speaking.

column6: a hopeless case, a person or situation having no hope of positive change
column8: It seems that Charles will never listen to our advice. I suppose it's a lost cause. The police searched for the missing girl for two weeks, but finally gave it up as a lost cause. Children who have committed several crimes as teenagers and show no sorrow about their actions are generally lost causes.

column6: mainly, especially
column8: Above all, don't mention the matter to Gerard; he's the last person we should tell. Sheila does well in all her school subjects, but above all in mathematics. Her math scores are always over 95 percent.

column6: survive or exist without something (also: to go without)
column8: With prices so high now, I'll have to do without a new suit this year. As a traveling salesperson, Monica can't do without a car. It's a shame that so many poor people in the world have to go without basic necessities of life such as nutritious food and suitable shelter.

column6: in the order of; on the authority of
column8: The students on the football team were ranked according to height, from shortest to tallest. According to my dictionary, you are using that word in your essay incorrectly.

column5: to be bound to do something
column6: to be certain to do something, to be sure to do something
column7: This idiom is used when the occurrence of an event seems inevitable or unavoidable.
column8: We are bound to be late if you don't hurry up. With the economy improving now, their business is bound to make more money this year.

column6: without doubt (also: for certain)
column8: In the dark, I couldn't tell for sure whether it was Polly or Sarah who drove by. I know for certain that Gene will move back to Washington next month.

column6: to perceive or understand as (S)
column7: This idiom is usually used when someone is mistakenly perceived. A noun or pronoun must separate the idiom.
column8: Because of his strong, muscular body, I took him for a professional athlete. As it turns out, he doesn't play any professional sports. What do you take me for — a fool? I don't believe what you're saying at all.

column6: to test, to use during a trial period (S)
column8: You can try out the new car before you decide to buy it. I can let you try the computer out for a few days before you make a decision.

column6: to destroy by making flat, to demolish (S)
column8: The construction company had to tear down the old hotel in order to build a new office building. The owners had to tear the house down after it burned down in a fire.

column6: to rip into small pieces (S)
column8: Deidre tore up the letter angrily and threw all the pieces into the trash can. He told the lawyer to tear the old contract up and then to prepare a new one.

column6: to be appreciated or accepted
column7: This idiom is usually followed by the adverb well. (In Lesson 6 this idiom has the meaning to review, as in the second sentence of the second example below.)
column8: The teacher's organized lessons always go over well with her students. The comedian's jokes weren't going over well; the audience wasn't laughing much at all. I think that the comedian should go over his material more carefully before each act.

column6: to exhaust the supply of, not to have more of
column8: We ran out of gas right in the middle of the main street in town. It's dangerous to run out of water if you are in an isolated area.

column6: basically, fundamentally
column7: This idiom is used to describe the true character of a person.
column8: James sometimes seems quite unfriendly, but at heart he's a good person. The Fares often don't see eye to eye, but at heart they both love each other very much.

column6: ready to, just going to
column8: We were about to leave the house when the phone rang. I'm sorry that I broke in. What were you about to say?

column6: to accept as a responsibility or task
column7: This idiom is often used when one accepts more responsibility than one can handle alone. It is usually used in the form to bite off more than one can chew.
column8: When I accepted the position of chairman, I didn't realize how much I was biting off. When James registered for 18 units in his last semester at college, he bit off more than he could chew.

column6: to distinguish between (also: to pick apart, to tell from) (S)
column8: The two brothers look so much alike that few people can tell them apart. That copy machine is so good that I can't pick the photocopy and the original apart. Most new cars are very similar in appearance. It's almost impossible to tell one from another.

column6: considering everything
column8: There were a few problems, but all in all it was a well-organized seminar. Leonard got a low grade in one subject, but all in all he's a good student.

column6: to distribute (also: to hand out) (S); to lose consciousness
column7: The verbal idiom to hand out can be made into the noun handout to refer to items that are distributed in a class or meeting.
column8: Please help me pass out these test papers; there must be a hundred of them. Alright, students, here are the class handouts for this week. The weather was so hot in the soccer stadium that some of the fans in the stands passed out.

column6: to be sufficient or adequate for everyone present; to circulate, to move from place to place
column8: We thought that we had bought enough food and drink for the party, but actually there wasn't enough to go around. There's a bad strain of influenza going around right now. Have you gotten your flu shots yet? Mike has been going around telling people that he was accepted to Harvard University. Do you believe him?

column6: to block or obstruct; not to be helpful, to cause inconvenience (for both, also: to get in the/one's way)
column8: Jocelyn couldn't drive through the busy intersection because a big truck was in the way. Our small child tried to help us paint the house, but actually he just got in our way.

column6: to gain (pounds or weight) (S); to present, to perform (S)
column8: Bob has put on a lot of weight recently. He must have put at least fifteen pounds on. The Youth Actor's Guild put on a wonderful version of Romeo and Juliet at the globe Theater.

column6: to construct, to erect (S); to lift, to raise upwards (S)
column8: The construction company is tearing down that old office building in order to put up a new one. Please put your hand up if you have never studied English grammar before.

column6: to tolerate, to accept unwillingly
column8: The employee was fired because his boss could not put up with his mistakes any longer. While I'm studying, I can't put up with any noise or other distractions.

column6: useless, without the desired result
column8: All the doctors' efforts to save the injured woman were in vain. She was declared dead three hours after being admitted to the hospital. We tried in vain to reach you last night. Is your phone out of order?

column6: continuously, constantly (also: day after day; for longer periods of time, year in and year out and year after year)
column8: During the month of April, it rained day in and day out. Day after day I waited for a letter from him, but one never came. Year in and year out, the weather in San Diego is the best in the nation.

column6: to work with the purpose of fulfilling a requirement or being equal to others
column7: The idiom is often followed by the preposition with and a noun phrase. It is similar in meaning to keep up with from Lesson 17.
column8: The student was absent from class so long that it took her a long time to catch up. If you are not equal to others, first you have to catch up with them before you can keep up with them.

column6: not to move (S)
column8: Please hold still while I adjust your tie. If you don't hold that camera still, you'll get a blurred picture.

column6: to recognize (S)
column7: This idiom is used when the person has been seen previously but is not known personally. The person must be used to separate the idiom.
column8: I have never met our new neighbors; I simply know them by sight. The woman said that she would know the thief by sight if she ever saw him again.

column6: to be unsatisfactory, to be improper, to be wrong
column7: In a question, this idiom is used with what or something. In an answer, something or nothing is usually used.
column8: A: What is the matter, Betty? You look very upset. B: Yes, something is the matter. I've lost my purse! A: Is something the matter, Charles? You don't look well. B: No, nothing is the matter. I'm just a little under the weather.

column6: to rear, to raise from childhood (S); to mention, to raise an issue, to introduce a topic (S)
column8: Parents should bring up their children to be responsible members of society. Sarah wanted to bring the scheduling problem up at the club meeting, but finally she decided against doing so. One of the students brought up an interesting point related to the subject in our textbook.

column6: to become lost; to go away in order not to bother
column7: The second definition provides a very informal, even rude, meaning that should be used only with close friends. It is sometimes used in a joking manner.
column8: While driving in Boston, we got lost and drove many miles in the wrong direction. Todd kept bothering me while I was studying, so I told him to get lost. Lisa joked that she wanted her sister to get lost forever.

column6: to delay, to make late (S); to remain high in quality
column8: A big accident held up traffic on the highway for several hours. Deidre is amazed at how well her car has held up over the years.

column6: to leave without permission; to escape
column8: The young couple ran away and got married because their parents wouldn't permit it. That cat is just like a criminal — it runs away from anyone who tries to come near!

column6: to refuse to consider, to prohibit (S)
column8: Heather ruled out applying to college in Texas because she would rather go to school in Canada. I'd like to watch a good movie on TV tonight, but a ton of homework rules that out.

column6: by a great margin, clearly
column8: Jacquie is by far the most intelligent student in our class. This is by far the hottest, most humid summer we've had in years.

column6: to say good-bye upon departure by train, airplane, bus, etc. (also: to send off) (S)
column7: A noun or pronoun must divide the idiom.
column8: We are going to the airport to see Peter off on his trip to Europe. When I left for Cincinnati on a business trip, no one came to the train station to send me off.

column6: to accompany a person out of a house, building, etc. (S)
column7: A noun or pronoun must again divide the idiom.
column8: The Johnsons were certain to see their guests out as each one left the party. Would you please see me out to the car? It's very dark outside.

column6: it's no surprise that, not surprisingly
column7: This idiom derives from reducing it is no wonder that…
column8: No wonder the portable heater doesn't work. It's not plugged into the electrical outlet! Jack has been out of town for several weeks. No wonder we haven't seen him recently.

column6: to increase (also: to drive up); to be constructed, to be erected
column7: The second definition is the same as the one for to put up in Lesson 19, except that to go up is not used with a noun object.
column8: Economists are predicting that consumer prices are going up. Inflation always has a tendency to drive up the cost of products. A new office is going up in the downtown area. A major construction company is putting it up.

column6: to approach (also: to come up to, to walk up to, to run up to, to drive up to, etc.)
column7: The related forms have the same meaning, but the type of movement is different.
column8: After the lecture, several people in the audience went up to the speaker to congratulate her. The little girl came up to me and shook my hand as if she had known me for years. Bill's friend didn't want to admit that they had gotten lost, but finally he agreed to drive up to a gas station and inquire about the correct route.

column6: to submit or deliver something that is due (S)
column8: Every student has to hand in an original composition each week of the semester. All the salespeople hand their weekly reports in on Friday.

column6: in order to be prepared if
column7: When the idiom occurs at the end of the sentence (the second example), then the meaning is in order to be prepared if something happens. The "something" might be an accident, a delay, etc.
column8: You'd better close the windows in case it rains. We should be sure to leave for the airport early, just in case. Cynthia, take one of your books in case you have some time to read on our trip.

column6: to disassemble, to separate the parts of something (S)
column7: A noun or pronoun usually divides this idiom.
column8: It is much easier to take a watch apart than it is to assemble it. The engine had a serious problem, so the mechanic had to take it apart completely in order to fix it.

column6: to assemble (S)
column7: A noun or pronoun usually divides this idiom. The preposition back is used when something has been disassembled and then is being reassembled, as in the second example.
column8: Todd followed the directions on the box but he couldn't manage to put the bicycle together properly. After the teenager took the broken video game apart and fixed it, he was unable to put it back together again.

column6: to be in a more favorable condition or situation
column7: The opposite of this idiom is to be worse off.
column8: Jim would be better off staying at home because of his cold. You'd be much better off working in an office than in a factory. The economies of some nations are worse off than they were several decades ago.

column6: to have enough money to enjoy a comfortable life, to be rich (also: to be well-to-do)
column8: They live in the best section of town in a large home; they are very well-off. By the time I reach the age of fifty-five, I hope to be well-to-do and to travel frequently.

column6: to surprise, to amaze, to astonish (S)
column7: A noun or pronoun usually divides this idiom.
column8: The offer of a high-paying position with another company took me by surprise. The president's announcement that the university was in financial trouble didn't take anyone by surprise.

column6: to maintain contact with (also: to stay in touch with)
column7: This idiom should be compared with to get in touch with in Lesson 9.
column8: You can telephone me every few days, and in that way we can keep in touch with each other. He promised to stay in touch with us while he was abroad. However, we were very disappointed that he never did get in touch with us.

column6: to give the same name as another (S)
column8: Helen's parents named Helen after her grandmother. My grandson is named after Calvin Coolidge, the 30th President of the United States.

column6: to grasp tightly or firmly; to wait, to be patient
column7: The second definition is often used when someone is talking on the telephone.
column8: The little girl held on to her mother's hand and refused to let go as they walked through the large crowd of people. (on the telephone) Could you please hold on a moment while I get a pencil and paper? Come on, Mike, hold on. I can't get ready so quickly.

column6: to visit or stop somewhere briefly in order to do something
column8: James had to stop by the registrar's office to submit a transcript request form. Let's stop by the supermarket and pick up a few grocery items.

column6: to write a note to someone (S)
column8: As soon as I get to Florida, I'll drop you a line and tell you about my new job. If you have time, drop me a line now and then while you're traveling.

column6: to meet or find unexpectedly (also: to run across); to be perceived or judged as (also: to come off)
column8: While Cheryl was cleaning the attic, she came across some very old coins. It took her by surprise to run across something like that. Jeff's boss comes across as a tough, unpleasant person, but actually Jeff says that he is a good employer. Some people come off quite differently than they really are.

column6: to represent, to signify; to tolerate
column7: The second definition is usually used in a negative sense. The meaning is the same as to put up with in Lesson 19.
column8: On the American flag, each star stands for one of the fifty states, and each stripe stands for one of the original thirteen colonies of the 1800s. The citizens wouldn't stand for the increase in crime in their city, so they hired more police officers and built another jail.

column6: to have the possibility of accomplishing something
column7: This idiom is often used with an adjective such as good or excellent. It also occurs in the negative, sometimes with the adjective much.
column8: The New York baseball team stands a good chance of winning the World Series this year. Because John doesn't have any previous work experience, he doesn't stand a chance of getting that job. The woman injured in the serious train accident doesn't stand much chance of surviving.

column6: to work carefully and conscientiously
column8: She takes pains to do everything well; she's our best employee. He took great pains with his last assignment because he needed to get an excellent grade to pass the class.

column6: to watch as a spectator, to observe
column8: Hundreds of people were looking on as the police and firefighters rescued the passengers in the wrecked train. I stayed with my son at his first soccer practice and looked on as the coach worked with the boys.

column6: to admire, to respect greatly
column8: Children will most certainly look up to their parents if the children are brought up well. Everyone looks up to the director of our department because he is a kind and generous person.

column6: to feel superior to, to think of someone as less important
column8: People who are in positions of power should be careful not to look down on those who work for them. Why does Alma look down on Mario; just because his family is so poor?

column6: to leave the ground (for airplanes); to leave, often in a hurry
column7: The noun form takeoff derives from this idiom.
column8: The plane took off over an hour late. The passengers had to buckle their seatbelts during takeoff. Do you have to take off already? You just arrived an hour ago!

column6: to succeed in doing something difficult (S); to exit to the side of a highway
column8: The group of investors pulled off a big deal by buying half the stock in that company. I wonder how they pulled it off before the company could prevent it. The motorist pulled off when the police officer turned on the red lights and the siren.

column6: to operate accurately (for watches and clocks)
column7: This idiom is usually used with adjectives such as good and perfect.
column8: Although this is a cheap watch, it keeps good time. The old clock keeps perfect time; it's never fast or slow.

column6: to manage, to cope
column7: This idiom is used when a person must accept a substitute that is not the most suitable.
column8: Pearl doesn't have a clean blouse so she has to make do with the one she wore yesterday. During difficult economic times, many people have to make do with less.

column6: to bear a human being or animal
column8: Jane's mother has just given birth to twin girls. The zoo's Siberian tiger just gave birth to a baby cub.

column6: a situation involving a narrow escape from danger (also: close shave)
column8: Bob, that car nearly hit us! What a close call. We had a close call when a small fire in our kitchen almost spread to the rest of the house.

column6: to annoy or disturb (also: to bug)
column8: Laura loves to talk to anyone. Sometimes her chatter really gets on my nerves. Jack asked his neighbor to turn down the stereo because it was bugging him and he couldn't concentrate.

column6: to suppress, to quell (S); to criticize unfairly (S)
column8: The police arrived just in time to put down the disturbance before it got very serious. Fred tries his best at playing tennis. You shouldn't put him down like that.

column6: to be sold at a certain price; to seek or strive for
column8: This dress probably goes for about $50, don't you think? Peter was going for first place in the swim meet, but he wasn't able to do better than third place.

column6: to have as an interest, such as a sport or hobby (also: to go for, to be into, to get into)
column8: Hal goes in for tennis while his wife goes in for painting and sculpture. What sports are you into? I don't have any time to get into sports.

column6: to remain awake, not to go to bed
column8: I want to stay up tonight and watch a late movie on TV. He stays up every night until after one o'clock, preparing his homework.

column6: to remain at home, not to go out
column7: An idiom with the opposite meaning is to stay out.
column8: On a rainy day, I like to stay in and read. Young people are able to stay out late at night and get very little sleep.

column6: to assume control or responsibility for (S); to do or perform again (S)
column7: The meaning of the second definition is almost the same as do over in Lesson 11. Also for the second definition, a noun or pronoun must divide the idiom.
column8: That large investment company specializes in taking over smaller businesses that are in financial trouble. Most students didn't do well on the important test, so the instructor let them take it over. Little Mikey didn't have much chance to hit the baseball during practice, so the coach let him take his turn over.

column6: to appear, to arrive; to be found or located (also for the second definition: to turn up)
column8: It really gets on my nerves that Ursula shows up late for every meeting. Willie hopes that the watch he lost last Sunday shows up soon. We've looked everywhere for that book, but it hasn't turned up yet.

column6: to empty, to tidy by removing (S); to steal, to rob (S); to buy or purchase all of something (S)
column8: It's time for you to clean out your closet so that you can store more things in there. A burglar entered my apartment while I was gone and cleaned me out. He took over $200 in cash and jewelry. Thousands of shoppers cleaned out the store that had gone bankrupt and was selling all its remaining products at very reduced prices.

column6: to make unconscious (S); to impress or attract greatly (S)
column7: This idiom can be made into the noun form knockout for both definitions.
column8: The prizefighter knocked out his opponent with one punch in the first five seconds of the first round. It was the fastest knockout in boxing history. Linda's beautiful appearance and slender figure really knock me out. Isn't she a real knockout tonight?

column6: to work very hard (sometimes too hard) to do something
column7: A reflexive pronoun must divide the idiom.
column8: She really knocked herself out trying to pass that difficult class. Don't knock yourself out during practice. Save your strength for the competition later.

column6: to accomplish, to execute (S) (also: to go through with)
column8: It's easy to write down a plan for losing weight, but much harder to carry it out. Charles promised to go through with his plan to enroll in graduate school and get an advanced degree.

column6: to meet someone unexpectedly; to crash or collide into (also: to bump into)
column8: It was a shock to run into an old friend from high school recently. The drunk driver was slightly injured when he ran into a telephone pole.

column6: to start traveling toward a place (also: to set off, to head out); to arrange or display neatly (also: to lay out) (S)
column8: We set out for the top of the mountain at dawn. Unfortunately, as we set off, it started to snow heavily, so we decided to head out again later. The children tried to set out the dishes on the table, but their dad had to help to lay the dishes out properly.

column5: to set out to do something
column6: to intend to, to act purposefully to
column8: We set out to paint the house in one day but quickly realized that it would be impossible to do so. Janet set out to compete for the large scholarship grant by writing a good essay.

column6: to create by drawing, such as a map (S); to prepare documents or legal papers (S)
column8: Max asked me to draw up a map to the party so that he wouldn't get lost. Our lawyer agreed to draw the contract up as soon as possible.

column6: compromise, cooperation between people
column8: Give and take is an important element of a successful marriage. Most business negotiations involve give and take between the parties involved.

column6: to stop attending; to withdraw from
column7: This idiom can be made into the noun form dropout.
column8: Some students drop out of secondary school early in order to get jobs. However, such dropouts often regret their decision later in life. Two more baseball teams have dropped out of the youth league due to a lack of players.

column6: to accept as true, have faith in
column8: Some people believe in being honest in all human affairs, while others accept the need to lie in order to get one's way. Throughout the history of man, some cultures have believed in one god while others have believed in the existence of many gods.

column6: to make happier, to feel less sad (S)
column8: We all tried to cheer up the little boy when he started to cry. After the death of Deanne's husband, it was difficult to cheer her up at all.

column6: to be sensible or reasonable
column8: It makes sense to wait until a sunny day to visit the park together. That Jimmy ran away from home suddenly doesn't make sense to any of us.

column6: to depart quickly (also: to storm out); to act suddenly
column7: For the second definition, this idiom is usually followed by a gerund form such as laughing, crying, singing, etc.
column8: Faye and Debbie were so angry at each other that one of them burst out the front door of the house and the other stormed out the back door. It was so funny to see a little baby in the audience burst out crying when the choir group burst out singing at the start of the recital.

column6: to get free, to escape
column8: We always try to get away from the noise and heat of the city for a month or two each summer. No one knows how the suspected criminal got away from the police.

column6: to avoid punishment for
column8: Jonathan tries to get away with coming late to work almost every day; someday he'll suffer the consequences. Terence can't continue to put his friends down like that and expect to get away with it forever.

column6: to receive one's just punishment (S)
column7: This idiom is usually used at the beginning of a sentence after the subject it. Compare the following examples with those in the previous idiom above.
column8: It serves Jonathan right to be fired from his job. It serves Terence right that none of his friends are willing to help him move to a new apartment.

column6: to prevent from sleeping (S); to continue maintaining (speed, level of work, condition, etc.) (S)
column8: Could you please turn down the TV volume? You're keeping up the children. If we can keep up this speed, we should arrive there in about two hours. James is so proud of his daughter for getting mostly A's in school. He's certain that she can keep up the good work. The Federal Reserve Bank hopes to keep the value of the dollar up at least through the rest of the year.

column6: to have current knowledge of; to understand as an explanation
column7: This idiom should be compared to the meaning of to keep up with in Lesson 17.
column8: Evan keeps up with world affairs by reading a news magazine each week. I understand a lot of the Spanish language, but I can't keep up with the fast conversation in this Mexican film.

column6: to be easily visible or noticeable (also: to stick out)
column7: This idiom is used for someone or something that is different from all others.
column8: Her bright red hair makes her stand out from others in the group. Brandon Styles is a tall, distinguished gentleman who sticks out in any crowd.

column6: to reveal or tell what you know, to hint
column8: We are going to the movies tonight and we don't want Doris to go. If you see her, make sure not to let on. They asked me not to let on to Ted that we're planning the birthday party; it's supposed to be a big surprise.

column6: to fail, to result badly
