column8: Something went wrong with the engine, so we had to have the car towed to a garage. Shawn should have been here over an hour ago; I'm certain that something went wrong.

column6: to compromise with someone
column8: Steve wanted $4,500 for his car, and Gwen offered $4,000. They met each other halfway and agreed on $4,250. After a long process of give and take, the owners of the company agreed to meet the workers halfway by providing some additional health benefits but no wage increase.

column6: to examine with the purpose of determining condition (also: to check on)
column7: This idiom has the related noun form checkup.
column8: The government always checks up on the background of employees who are hired for sensitive military projects. The doctor wants me to have a thorough medical checkup as part of a preventive medicine program.

column6: to point or place upwards (S); to rob (S)
column8: You should put some water on your hair. It's sticking up in the back. A masked thief stuck up a grocery store in the neighborhood last night.

column6: to happen
column8: I didn't find any explanation in the newspaper about how the political coup came about. The flood came about as a result of the heavy winter rains.

column6: to cause to happen
column7: This idiom is used to indicate who or what caused something to come about.
column8: John brought about the accident because of his carelessness. The heavy rains we have each spring bring about serious flooding.

column6: to increase slowly, to make stronger gradually (S)
column8: They built up their savings account so that they could buy a new house. The professional athlete exercises regularly to build her strength up.

column6: to decrease, to lessen in strength
column8: The hurricane became a less serious tropical storm when its winds died down. We let the fire in the fireplace die down and enjoyed watching the embers as they glowed in the dark.

column6: to diminish gradually in time or distance
column8: The memory of that unpleasant experience has slowly faded away. The music of the band gradually faded away as the parade passed down the street.

column6: not to exist anymore; to be in the process of disappearing
column8: Scientists still are not sure exactly why the dinosaurs died out. That strange, new style of dancing is slowly dying out.

column6: to read or see clearly (S); to prepare a legal document, such as a will, a check, etc. (S)
column8: The letter was so poorly handwritten that I couldn't make out many of the words. Harold, please make the check out to Acme Piano Company.

column6: to fulfill (a standard or promise)
column8: It was clear that the lazy student would never live up to his family's expectations. It surprised us that the car salesperson lived up to all the promises he made.

column6: to adhere to (a promise), to follow or obey (a set of rules, procedures, etc.)
column8: He made a promise to his wife to quit smoking and drinking, and so far he has stuck to it. All organizations expect their employees to stick to established work rules and procedures. If you try hard to stick to your principles, then you'll be able to live up to them.

column6: to cheat, to take unfair advantage of (also: to rip off, the ripoff)
column8: Be careful in doing business with that salesperson. He'll stick it to you at the first opportunity. The car dealership certainly ripped me off when I bought this car. It has caused me trouble constantly. You paid over $400 for that jacket? What a ripoff!

column6: to insist on, to demand; to defend, to support
column8: If you don't stand up for your rights in court, the lawyers will try to stick it to you. Frank stood up for his friend, who was being put down by other teenagers nearby.

column6: to economize, to save money
column8: Most students live on limited budgets and have to cut corners whenever possible. The Livingstons have nine children, so it is essential that they cut corners at all times.

column6: to employ, to hire (S); to accept responsibility for, to undertake
column8: That factory is taking a lot of new employees on for its new production line. Would you be willing to take on the task of organizing the next company picnic?

column6: to remove from an elevated place (S); to write what is said, to note
column8: We should take the pictures down from the wall and clean off the dust. The secretary took down everything that was said at the meeting.

column6: to fail to materialize, not to succeed
column7: This idiom is usually used with the noun plan or plans as the subject.
column8: Our plan to travel to Europe last summer fell through when we were unable to save up enough money. Felix made plans to have a party for everyone in his office, but they fell through at the last moment.

column6: to lag, to fail to keep up (also: to get behind)
column8: Eve fell behind in her studies and finally had to drop out of school. If you get behind in your car payments, the finance company may repossess it from you.

column6: to surrender, to stop resisting
column8: Completely surrounded by our soldiers, the enemy finally gave in. Management gave in to the strikers' demands and agreed to a shortened work week.

column6: to release, to produce
column8: When water boils, it gives off steam. The flowers in this garden give off a strange odor.

column6: to distribute; to become exhausted or depleted (also: to run out)
column7: The first definition has the same meaning as the second definition of to pass out in Lesson 19.
column8: An usher stood at the door of the theater giving out programs. I couldn't finish the ten-mile race because my energy gave out. Jeff plans to stay in Las Vegas and gamble until his money runs out.

column6: to want revenge on, to feel hostile towards (also: to hold a grudge against)
column8: Martina expects to lose her job because her boss has had it in for her for a long time. The teacher has held a grudge against Al ever since the time that he insulted her in front of the class.

column6: to quarrel with, to confront
column8: I am going to have it out with Jack about all the times that he has told us lies. Ben had it out with his roommate about coming back home so late and making a lot of noise.

column6: to delay, or to be delayed, in occurring (S)
column7: This idiom has the same meaning as to put off in Lesson 5 when a noun or pronoun is used as an object, as in the second example.
column8: If the rain holds off for a few more days, they can finish planting the rest of the crop. The judge agreed to hold off making a decision until new evidence could be introduced into court.

column6: to endure, to be sufficient; to survive by resisting; to persist in one's efforts
column7: The first definition for to hold out has the opposite meaning of the second definition for to give out (seventh idiom, this lesson).
column8: If our supply of food and water holds out, we plan to camp here for another week. However, whenever it gives out, we'll have to leave. That nation's troops cannot hold out much longer against the superior forces of the enemy. The valuable football player held out for more money before signing a new contract with his team.

column6: to extend, to keep for a longer time (S)
column8: They are going to hold over that movie for another week because so many people are coming to see it. Let's hold discussion of this problem over until our next meeting.

column6: to slacken, to lessen in intensity; to relax or ease one's effort (also: related idiom: to take it easy)
column8: If the rain doesn't let up soon, we won't be able to have our picnic. When Jane is working, she never lets up for a moment. Jane should take it easy or she'll get exhausted.

column6: to abstain from, stop using as a habit; to release or discharge from a job (also: related idiom: to let go) (S)
column8: If you're trying to lose weight, you should lay off sweet things. If business continues to be slow, we will have to lay off some workers. It will be necessary to let the youngest employees go first.

column6: to show or introduce (to the public) (S); to make available (S)
column8: Most automobile companies bring out new models each year. My mother brought some snacks out for my friends and me to have.

column6: to return a bought or borrowed item (also: to take back) (S)
column7: To bring back is used when you are speaking at the place that an item is bought or borrowed; To take back is used when speaking at another place.
column8: Ma'am, our store policy is that you can bring back the dress as long as you have your sales receipt. You can borrow my car if you promise to bring it back by six o'clock. I have to take this book back to the library today.

column6: to wait until late at night without going to bed
column8: Don't wait up for me. I may be back after midnight. We waited up for our son until two o'clock in the morning before we called the police.

column6: not to disturb, to stay away from (S) (also: to let alone)
column8: Leave the baby alone for a while and she may go to sleep. After the cat had scratched Peter twice, he let it alone.

column6: and certainly not (also: not to mention, to say nothing of)
column7: Let alone is used after negative forms. The example that follows let alone is much less possible than the example that precedes let alone.
column8: I'm too sick today to walk to the kitchen, let alone go to the zoo with you. He doesn't even speak his own language well, let alone French.

column6: to terminate, to discontinue (S)
column8: After war began, the two countries broke off diplomatic relations. Elsa and Bob were once engaged, but they have already broken it off.

column6: to disappear gradually
column8: My headache isn't serious. It will wear off after an hour or so. The effect of the painkilling drug didn't wear off for several hours.

column6: to become worn gradually through use (also: to wear away, to wear through) (S)
column7: Compare with to wear out (to become useless from wear) in Lesson 8.
column8: If you drag your feet while you walk, you'll wear down your shoes quickly. The pounding of ocean waves against the coast gradually wears it away. Johnny has worn through the seat of his pants. Helga threw away that dress because she had worn it out.

column6: in general, in most ways (also: by and large)
column8: He is, on the whole, a good student. By and large, I agree with your suggestions.

column6: risky, uncertain until the end
column8: The complicated medical operation was touch and go for several hours. The outcome of the soccer final was touch and go for the entire match.

column6: to exercise; to develop, to devise (a plan) (S)
column8: Jane works out at the fitness center every other morning before going to school. The advertising department worked out a plan to increase company sales. We couldn't come up with a good plan for solving the problem, but we agreed to work it out at a later date.

column6: to drive or go backwards (S); to defend, to support (S); to return to a previous thought
column8: I couldn't back my car up because there was a bicycle in the driveway behind me. Ursula asked her friends to go back her up when she went to court to fight a ticket for an illegal lane change on the highway. Wait a minute. Could you back up and say that again?

column6: to drive a vehicle out of a parking space (S); to withdraw support, to fail to fulfill a promise or obligation
column8: The parking lot attendant had to back another car out before he could get to mine. We were all ready to sign the contracts when one of the parties to the agreement backed out.

column5: to have one's heart set on
column6: to desire greatly, to be determined to
column8: She has her heart set on taking a trip abroad. She's been thinking about it for months. Todd has his heart set on going to medical school and becoming a doctor.

column6: to buy the complete stock of (S)
column8: Before the hurricane struck, residents bought up all the food and water in local stores. The government plans to buy up all surplus grain in order to stabilize the price.

column6: to purchase a business or company (S); to purchase all of a person's shares or stock (S)
column7: This idiom is similar in meaning to take over in Lesson 23.
column8: Larger companies often buy out smaller companies that are having financial difficulties. Mr. Lee has been trying for some time to buy his partner out so that he can control the company by himself.

column6: to sell all items (S); to arrange for the sale of a company or business (S)
column8: That store is closing its doors for good and is selling out everything this weekend. If my new business enterprise is successful, I'll sell it out for a few million dollars.

column6: to become popular or widespread; to understand, to appreciate a joke
column7: This idiom is often used with the preposition to for the second definition.
column8: Fashions of the past often catch on again among young people. When the teacher speaks quickly like that, can you catch on easily? His joke was very funny at the time, but when I told it to others later, nobody seemed to catch on. I had to tell the joke again before anyone could catch on to it.

column6: to have the necessary skills or talent for
column7: The idiom is most often used in the negative or in questions.
column8: John is certainly not cut out for the work of a trial lawyer. Are you certain that you are cut out for that kind of job?

column6: to discard (S); to remove by force (S); to refuse to consider, to reject (S)
column8: Instead of throwing out our paper waste in the office, we should recycle it. When a fight broke out between two people on the dance floor, the management threw them out. The judge threw the case out because there was insufficient evidence to try the defendant successfully.

column6: to erect or construct quickly (S); to vomit (S)
column8: The Red Cross threw up temporary shelters for the homeless victims of the earthquake. The ill patient is unable to digest her food properly, so she is throwing all of it up.

column6: to make understandable (also: to straighten out) (S); to become sunny
column8: The teacher tried to clear up our confusion about the meaning of the difficult paragraph in the reading. It's rather cloudy this morning. Do you think that it will clear up later?

column6: to go, or cause to go, more slowly (also: to slow up) (S)
column7: This idiom can be used both with and without an object.
column8: The car was going so fast that the motorist couldn't slow it down enough to make the sharp curve. You're eating too fast to digest your food well. Slow down! Slow up a bit! You're talking so quickly that I can't catch on well.

column6: to lose, or cause to lose, all moisture (S); to be depleted
column8: Every summer the extreme heat in this valley dries the stream up. All funds for the project dried up when the local government faced a budget crisis.

column6: to lose, or cause to lose, moisture gradually (S); to stop drinking alcohol in excess (also: to sober up)
column8: Martha hung the towel outside on the clothesline in order to dry it out. Some people go to alcohol recovery centers in order to dry out.

column6: to be doing something; to be planning or plotting something, scheming
column7: The first definition usually takes the form of a question.
column8: Hi, Jake. I haven't seen you in a long time. What have you been up to? Those boys hiding behind the building must be up to something bad.

column6: to avoid discussing directly, to evade the issue
column8: Our boss beats around the bush so much that no one in the office knows exactly what he wants us to do. Instead of beating around the bush, Melinda explained her objection in very clear terms.

column6: to end, to stop
column7: This idiom is used with finally and never when some activity lasts too long.
column8: The meeting finally came to an end at ten o'clock in the evening. Even though my friend seemed to enjoy the movie, I thought that it would never come to an end.

column6: to cause to end, to terminate in a definite manner (also: to do away with)
column8: The dictatorial government put an end to organized opposition in the country by making it illegal to form a political party. It may never be possible to do away with all forms of prejudice and discrimination in the world.

column6: to seek revenge, to retaliate
column7: This idiom is similar in meaning to to have it in for in Lesson 27.
column8: Bill has had it in for his boss for a long time. He told me he's planning to get even with his boss by giving some company secrets to a competitor. I want to get even with Steve for beating me so badly in tennis last time. The scores were 6-1 and 6-2.

column6: to waste time (also: to screw around); to joke, not to be serious
column8: The teacher got angry because her students were fooling around and couldn't finish their work before the end of class. Sometimes I wish that Pat would stop fooling around so much and talk about something more interesting to others.

column6: to face, to overlook
column8: We really enjoy our new apartment that looks out on a river. Their rear window looks out on a lovely garden.

column6: to cause anger (S); to create (trouble or difficulty) (S)
column8: The senseless murder of a small child stirred up the whole neighborhood. The boss is in a bad mood today so don't stir her up with any more customer complaints.

column6: to visit in order to enjoy (S); to decrease the size of clothes (S); to deceive, to fool (S)
column8: We decided to take in Toronto on our trip to Canada, and that is where we took in the most memorable outdoor stage play we have ever seen. Lois lost so much weight that she had her skirts and slacks taken in by her tailor. The fraudulent investment advisor took everyone in with his sincere manner and generous promises. Most investors lost all their money.

column6: to undergo, to experience; to consume, to use (also: to use up)
column7: The first definition is used when someone is having some hardship or difficulty.
column8: I can't believe what she went through to get that job. She had four interviews with the hiring committee in one week! Frank said that they had gone through all the toilet paper in the house, but Steve couldn't believe that they had used it all up.

column6: to be known without the need to mention
column7: This idiom occurs with a that-clause, often with the pronoun it as the subject.
column8: It goes without saying that you shouldn't drive quickly in bad weather. That he will gain weight if he continues to eat and drink so much goes without saying.

column6: to mislead by joking or tricking (S)
column7: This idiom is usually used in a continuous tense form. A noun object must divide the idiom.
column8: Don't worry. I wouldn't expect you do all that work by yourself. I'm just putting you on. Jack can't be serious about what he said. He must be putting us on.

column6: to remain calm during an emergency
column8: When the heater caused a fire, Gloria kept her head and phoned for assistance right away; otherwise, the whole house might have burned down. When the boat starting sinking in heavy seas, the crew members kept their heads and led the passengers to the lifeboats.

column6: not to think clearly, to lose one's self-control
column8: When Mel saw a dog in the street right in front of his car, he lost his head and drove onto the sidewalk and into a tree. If the politician hadn't gotten stirred up and lost his head, he never would have criticized his opponent unfairly.

column6: not willing to accept the ideas of others (the opposite of narrow minded is broad-minded)
column8: Narrow-minded people tend to discriminate against groups of people with which they have nothing in common. Ted is so broad-minded that he has almost no standards by which he judges others.

column6: to withstand use or wear; to fail to appear for a date or social engagement (S)
column8: My old car has stood up well over the years. I haven't had any major problems at all. Janet was very angry because her new boyfriend stood her up on their second date. She waited over an hour for him before returning home.

column6: to win or defeat by gaining an advantage over someone
column8: Jim doesn't seem very athletic at tennis, but if you're not careful, he'll get the better of you. Lynn gets frustrated when Bruce gets the better of her in arguments. No matter what she says, he always has a clever response.

column6: to become free or loose, to escape
column8: During the bad storm, the boat broke loose from the landing and drifted out to sea. One bicyclist broke loose from the pack of racers and pulled ahead towards the finish line.

column6: nervous, anxious; upset, irritable
column8: Cynthia was on edge all day about the important presentation she had to give to the local citizens group. I don't like being around Jake when he's on edge like that. Someone should tell him to calm down and relax.

column6: not be able to convince someone
column7: This idiom is used when someone is wasting time trying to convince another person. The idiom to save one's breath is related and means not to waste effort trying to convince someone.
column8: Don't argue with Frank any longer. You are wasting your breath trying to get him to agree with you. I have already decided what I'm going to do. You can't change my mind, so save your breath.

column6: to make shorter, to interrupt (S)
column8: The moderator asked the speaker to cut short his talk because there wasn't much time remaining for questions from the audience. We were very unfortunate when we received bad news from home that forced us to cut our trip short.

column6: to become involved or concerned with something; to enter a place for a brief time (also: to step into)
column8: When the children started fighting on the play-ground, a teacher had to step in and stop the fight. The supervisor asked one of the employees to step in her office for a moment. Would you step into the hallway so that I can show you the information posted on the bulletin board?

column6: to retire or leave a top position, to resign
column8: Next May the principal will step down after thirty-five years of service to the school. The angry shareholders wanted the company president to step down because of the stock scandal.

column6: to treat severely, to discipline; to go faster, to work more quickly
column7: For the second definition, the idiom is followed by the pronoun it.
column8: Sometimes it's necessary to step on children when they do something dangerous. We're going to be late for the movies. You'd better step on it!

column6: very inexpensive, a bargain
column7: This idiom is often used in an exclamation using what.
column8: I can't believe that I paid only $2,000 for this three-year-old car. What a steal! Scott considered it a steal when he bought a complete bedroom set for only $99.

column6: to behave so as to gain favor with someone
column8: The other students in the class resent Jim because he plays up to the teacher in order to get better grades. When my children asked me to go shopping for a new video game, I knew why they had been playing up to me all morning.

column6: approximately, almost; somewhat, to a certain degree
column8: Although your bedroom feels smaller, it's more or less the same size as mine. Ted more or less agreed with our decision to put off the meeting until more members could show up. At least he didn't object strongly.

column6: to confuse, to scramble (S); to cause problems in (S)
column8: Chris had trouble finding Jane's apartment because the addresses of the buildings screwed him up. Instead of fixing the television set, the technician screwed it up even more.

column6: to perform badly, to make a mistake (also: to mess up, to slip up)
column8: I really goofed up on the exam today; did you mess up, too? Karen slipped up when she forgot to deposit money into her checking account.

column5: to go off the deep end
column6: to get very angry and do something hastily
column8: Just because you had a serious argument with your supervisor, you didn't have to go off the deep end and resign, did you? When Dan's wife demanded a divorce, he went off the deep end again. This time he was shouting so that the whole neighborhood could hear.

column6: to fail at what one used to do well
column8: Milton used to be the best salesman at the car dealership, but recently he seems to have lost his touch. I used to play tennis very well, but today you beat me easily. I must be losing my touch.

column6: under firm control, well managed
column8: The copilot asked the pilot if he had the plane in hand or whether he needed any help navigating through the severe thunderstorm. The police officer radioed to the station that she had the emergency situation in hand and didn't require any assistance.

column6: available, nearby
column7: This idiom is often followed by in case.
column8: I always keep some extra money on hand in case I forget to get cash from the bank. The concert organizers arranged to have some security guards on hand in case there were any problems during the performance.

column6: to discuss informally (over a period of time) (S) (also: to toss around)
column8: At first my friends were reluctant to consider my suggestion, but they finally were willing to kick it around for a while. Herb thought that we should kick around the idea of establishing a special fund for supporting needy members of the club.

column6: be attentive, competent, alert
column8: Jim was the only one who caught that serious error in the bookkeeping statements. He's really on the ball. Ella was certainly on the ball when she remembered to reconfirm our flight arrangements. All the rest of us would have forgotten.

column6: to meet or fulfill a missed obligation at a later time (S); to create, to invent (an idea) (S); to apply cosmetics to (S); to comprise, to be composed of
column7: Note that all of the definitions are separable except the last one.
column8: The teacher allowed several students who missed the exam to make it up during the next class. The little boy made up a bad excuse for wearing his dirty shoes in the house, so his mother punished him. Dee was able to make her face up in half the normal time because she didn't use much makeup. Two separate bodies — the House of Representatives and the Senate — make up the Congress of the United States.

column6: to resolve differences with
column7: This idiom is used for differences of opinion between friends and lovers.
column8: Gundula made up with her roommate after their serious misunderstanding about arrangements for the party. After the bad quarrel the two lovers kissed and made up with each other.

column6: to gather, to collect (information) (S); to gain control of one's emotions (S)
column7: A reflexive pronoun must be used for the second definition.
column8: The reporter pulled together information from several sources in preparing the newspaper article. Mr. Simpson was so frightened when he heard footsteps behind him on the lonely, dark street that it took several minutes to pull himself together.

column6: to appear promising or optimistic, to be improving
column7: This idiom is used in a continuous tense, very often with the subject things.
column8: The board chairman is glad to report that things are looking up for the company after several years of declining sales. Prospects for building that new library in the downtown area are looking up.

column6: to stop a bad habit
column8: Once a child becomes accustomed to chewing his nails, it's difficult to kick the habit. The doctor advised the heavy cigarette smoker that her heart had become damaged and that she should kick the habit right away.

column6: to conceal, to hide (S)
column7: This idiom is used for events which are potentially embarrassing to one's reputation, as well as against the law. The noun coverup can be formed.
column8: The office worker tried to cover up his crimes, but everyone knew that he had been stealing office supplies all along. The political coverup of the bribery scandal failed and was reported by all the major media.

column6: to fall asleep; to take to a certain location (S); to decrease (for the third definition, also: to fall off)
column8: My mother dropped off during the boring television show; her head was nodding up and down. I don't mind dropping you off at the store on my way to work. Business has been dropping off rapidly recently, but fortunately it hasn't been falling off as quickly as for our competitors.

column6: to place upside down (S); to flip, to turn upside down; to pass or give control to someone (S)
column8: The teacher asked the students to turn the answer sheet over and to write a short essay on the back. The car was going too fast around the corner and turned over twice. Mr. Collins has decided to turn over his jewelry store to his son at the end of the year.

column6: to send a request through the normal way
column7: This idiom can be used with the adjective proper.
column8: If you go through proper channels in this company, it's sometimes impossible to get anything done quickly. The police told the important civic leader that even she had to go through channels in reporting the burglary of her house.

column6: the final event in a series of unacceptable actions
column7: This idiom is always used with the definite article the.
column8: When John asked to borrow money from me for the fourth time, it was the last straw. I finally told him that I couldn't lend him any more. I can't believe that my roommate left the door to our apartment unlocked again. It's the last straw; I'm moving out.

column6: to become unable or afraid to do something
column7: This idiom is usually used in the case of an important or dangerous action.
column8: Karl was supposed to marry Elaine this weekend, but at the last moment he got cold feet. Only one of the rock climbers got cold feet when the group reached the base of the hundred-meter cliff.

column6: to receive credit for the value of an old item towards the purchase of a new item (S)
column7: This idiom is used to form the noun trade-in.
column8: The car dealership offered me $1,000 for my old car if I traded it in for a new model. The appliance company was offering a $50 trade-in during the special promotion for its new line of refrigerators.

column6: direct, personal; directly, personally (written without hyphens)
column7: This idiom can be used both as an adjective (the first definition) and as an adverb (the second definition).
column8: The workers' representatives had a face-to-face meeting with the management to resolve the salary issue. The stepmother and her teenage son talked face to face about his troubles in school.

column6: to support, to back (also: to go along with); to understand or follow what someone is saying
column8: Although others thought that we shouldn't go along with Jerry, I told Jerry that I was with him on his proposal for reorganizing the staff. After turning left at the traffic light, go two blocks and turn right on Madison. After three more blocks, turn right again. Are you still with me?

column6: to be able to focus or concentrate on (also: to get with it)
column7: To be with it in the negative has the same meaning as to feel out of it. The related form to get with it is used in commands.
column8: Jack's really with it today. I've never seen him play such good soccer. You've done only a small amount of work in two hours. You're not with it today, are you? It's no excuse to say that you feel out of it. We need everyone's help on this, so get with it!

column6: to fall in love quickly; to be fooled or tricked by
column8: Samantha and Derek never expected to fall for each other like they did, but they got married within two weeks of having met. The Masons wanted to believe their son, but unfortunately they had fallen for his lies too many times to be deceived once again.

column6: it seems likely, reasonable, or typical
column7: This idiom is either followed by a that-clause or by no other part of grammar.
column8: It figures that the children were willing to help with the yardwork only if they received a reward for doing so. When I told Evan that his secretary was unhappy about not getting a raise, he said that it figured.

column6: to inform, to give background information to (also: to clue in) (S)
column7: This idiom is often followed by the preposition on and a noun phrase containing the pertinent information.
column8: Could you fill me in on what is going to be discussed at tomorrow's meeting? Not having been to the convention, my associate asked me to clue him in on the proceedings.

column6: to motivate to behave or act in a certain way (S)
column7: This idiom is used within a what-clause.
column8: If a salesperson knows what makes a customer tick, he will be able to sell a lot of merchandise. It's been impossible for us to figure out what makes our new boss tick. One moment she seems pleasant and then the next moment she's upset.

column6: to take someone's place temporarily, to substitute for; to protect someone by lying or deceiving
column8: Go ahead and take your coffee break. I'll cover for you until you return. The criminal made his wife cover for him when the police asked if the man had been home all day. She swore that he had been there.

column6: to provide a person with another opportunity or chance (S); not to expect too much work from (S); not to expect someone to believe (S)
column7: Command forms are most common with this idiom. For the third definition, the pronoun me must be used.
column8: The driver pleaded with the police officer to give him a break and not issue him a ticket for speeding. When the students heard how much homework the teacher wanted them to do over the holiday, they begged, "Give us a break, Professor Doyle!" Oh, Jim, give me a break! That's a terrible excuse for being late.

column6: to stop doing as a regular activity, to remove oneself from a situation
column7: The related idiom to want out indicates that someone desires to bow out.
column8: She bowed out as the school's registrar after sixteen years of service. One of the two partners wanted out of the deal because they couldn't agree on the terms of the contract.

column6: to find guilty of a crime or offense (S) (also: to hang on)
column7: This idiom is divided by a noun phrase containing the crime or offense. The accused person is mentioned after the preposition on.
column8: The prosecuting attorney tried to pin the murder on the victim's husband, but the jury returned a verdict of "not guilty." I wasn't anywhere near the window when it got broken. You can't pin that on me.

column5: to get a rise out of
column6: to provoke a response from
column7: This idiom is usually used when someone is teased into responding in anger or annoyance.
column8: You can kid me all day about my mistake, but you won't get a rise out of me. I got a rise out of Marvin when I teased him about his weight. Marvin weighs over two-hundred pounds.

column6: to stay or remain where one is, to wait
column7: This idiom is used when someone is waiting for something to happen or for someone to arrive.
column8: Todd had to stick around the house all day until the new furniture was finally delivered in the late afternoon. Why don't you stick around for a while and see if Sarah eventually shows up?

column6: to pay the cost or bill
column7: This idiom applies when someone pays for the cost of another person's meal, tickets, etc.
column8: The advertising manager is flying to Puerto Rico for a conference, and her firm is picking up the tab. The government picked up the tab for the visiting dignitary. It paid for all of the lodging and meals, as well as transportation, during his stay.

column6: incidentally
column7: This idiom is used when someone thinks of something further in the course of a conversation.
column8: Movies are my favorite form of entertainment. Oh, by the way, have you seen the new picture that's playing at the Bijou? Vera's been divorced for three years now. She told me, by the way, that she never plans to remarry.

column6: to do something with enthusiasm and thoroughness
column8: Our interior decorator really went to town in remodeling our living room. I'm afraid to ask how much it's going to cost. Charlie really went to town on his research project. He consulted over forty reference works and wrote a ninety-page report.

column6: to neglect a duty (S); to ignore a situation (S)
column8: Terry knew that she should have paid the electric bill on time instead of letting it slide. Now the utility company has turned off her service. When he tried to get a rise out of me by mentioning my failure to receive a promotion at work, I just let it slide.

column6: I don't know (also: beats me)
column7: This idiom is used informally, usually as a command form.
column8: When Elmer asked his wife if she knew why the new neighbors left their garage door open all night, she responded, "Search me." When I asked Dereck why his girlfriend wasn't at the party yet, he said, "Beats me. I expected her an hour ago."

column6: to express one's true feelings (S)
column7: This idiom is used when someone has long waited to express themselves.
column8: Ellen felt a lot better when she finally talked to a counselor and got the problem off her chest. Faye hasn't shared her concern about her marriage with her husband yet. I think that she should get it off her chest soon.

column6: to spend money freely, to live luxuriously
column8: Kyle and Eric saved up money for two years so that they could travel to Europe and live it up. After receiving a large inheritance from a rich aunt, I was able to live it up for years.

column6: to energize, to make more active (also: to pick up) (S)
column8: The teacher occasionally took the class on field trips just to liven things up a bit. The animals in the zoo began to liven up when evening came and the temperatures dropped. Many people have to drink coffee every morning just to pick themselves up.

column6: to share involvement in
column8: The new vice-president was promised that she would have a voice in developing the company's international expansion. The students are trying to have a voice in college affairs by gaining representation on administrative committees.

column6: to register at a hotel or motel; to leave or deposit for transporting or safekeeping (S)
column7: The adjective form check-in derives from this idiom.
column8: Courtney arrived in town at mid-day and promptly checked in at the Plaza Hotel. The hotel permitted an early check-in time. There were dozens of people at the airline counters waiting to check their bags in for their flights.

column6: to pay the bill at a hotel or motel and then leave; to investigate, to examine (S)
column7: The adjective form check-out derives from this idiom.
column8: The latest you should check out of the hotel is 12 noon. However, in your case, we can set a special check-out time of 2:00 P.M. The police received a call from someone claiming to have witnessed a murder. The police sent two detectives to check the call out right away.

column5: to take somebody at one's word
column6: to accept what one says as true, to believe
column8: When he offered to be responsible for the fund raiser, I took him at his word. Now he's saying that he's not available to do it. You should be careful about taking her at her word. She's been known to say one thing but to do another.

column6: to be useful, to suit one's needs or requirements
column8: I don't have a screwdriver to open this, but I think that a knife will serve the purpose. Jane prefers working to studying, so it served her purpose to drop out of school and take that job.

column6: very much, greatly
column8: Jim and Claudia want to have children in the worst way. They are trying very hard to conceive. Because Umer has relatives in Turkey, he wants to visit there in the worst way.

column6: to avoid one's responsibility, to quit
column7: This idiom is an informal version of the second definition to back out (lesson 29). The noun form copout means an excuse for avoiding responsibility.
column8: Evelyn had agreed to help us with arrangements for the party, but she copped out at the last minute. I can't believe that Cindy offered such an explanation for failing to show up. What a poor copout!

column6: to form a line; to arrange to have, to manage to obtain (S)
column8: The moviegoers lined up in front of the theater showing the most popular film of the summer. Rob is going to schedule the famous author to speak at the convention if he can line her up in time.

column6: to get excited, angry, or flustered
column8: Despite the boos from some in the audience, the actors on stage never lost their cool. Although the group of skiers were in danger from an apparent avalanche, their ski guide never lost his cool.

column6: to delay making a decision on (S)
column8: In making up the job announcement, the firm decided to leave the salary open until a qualified candidate was found. We know that the annual summer camp will be held in August, but let's leave the exact dates open for now.

column6: to interest greatly, to excite (S)
column7: The idiom with the opposite meaning is to turn off. These idioms are used to form the nouns turnon and turnoff.
column8: Does great art turn you on? I find going to a museum and viewing classic works of art a real turnon. Going to a bar and having silly conversation with strangers really turns me off. In fact, most bar scenes are really turnoffs to me.

column6: to lose an opportunity, to fail in some undertaking
column8: The precious metals market was looking up several months ago, but unfortunately most investors missed the boat. Mr. Vlasic's new business went bankrupt within a short time. He really missed the boat by opening a tanning salon near the beach.

column6: to invent, to create (also: to dream up)
column7: This idiom is often used for an unusual or foolish thought.
column8: Who thought up the idea of painting the living room walls bright red? When asked by the teacher why she was late, the student dreamed up a plausible excuse.

column6: to introduce an unexpected topic, causing embarrassment (S)
column8: The first week of class was going very well until a student threw the teacher a curve by suggesting that the textbook was too difficult. The director asked us in advance to stick to the meeting agenda and not to throw him any curves.

column6: to create a disturbance, usually by complaining
column7: This idiom is similar in meaning to the previous idiom, but the emphasis is on the aspect of complaining rather than causing embarrassment.
column8: In most companies, an employee who makes waves is not appreciated. The meeting was going smoothly until one of the participants made waves about the newly revised compensation package.

column6: to continue as before; to conduct, to engage in; to behave in an immature manner
column8: Even in the face of disaster, the inhabitants carried on as though nothing had happened. The business associates decided to carry on their discussion in the hotel bar instead of the conference room. I can't believe that John carried on so much just because his dog died. He looked depressed and cried for weeks after it happened.

column6: absolutely not (also: no way)
column7: This idiom is used as a kind of exclamation by itself.
column8: You're asking me to invest in that poorly rated company just because you know the son of the president? Not on your life! When a friend tried to get Mark to jump out of a plane with a parachute, he immediately responded, "No way!"

column6: to be extensive, to discuss much material
column7: Forms such as a lot of, too much, too little are used before the noun ground.
column8: That national commission's report on urban ghettos covers a lot of ground. Many of the recommendations are too costly to implement. In his first lecture on Greek philosophers, I thought that our professor covered too little ground.

column6: to be responsible for an office while others are gone
column8: It seems that all of our employees are taking a lunch break at the same time. I wonder who's minding the store. Lynne agreed to mind the store while the others went outside to watch the parade passing by.

column6: to punish with full penalty, to be harsh on
column8: Because the criminal was a repeat offender, the judge threw the book at him with heavy fines and a long prison term. My boss threw the book at me when he discovered that I had been using company time for personal business. I was severely reprimanded and forced to make up the lost time.

column6: to say or do the wrong thing
column7: This idiom is used with the noun phrase one's mouth or the pronoun it.
column8: Fred really put his foot in his mouth when he called his supervisor by the wrong name. I really put my foot in it when I forgot my girlfriend's birthday and didn't buy her anything. She almost lost her cool.

column6: to become available to others
column7: This idiom is used when something is highly desirable to many other people.
column8: When one of the full-time contract instructors stepped down, her nice office overlooking the river was up for grabs. Did you know that Senator Stone is retiring and that her Senate seat is up for grabs?

column6: to display one's ability in order to attract attention (S); to let others see, to expose to public view (S)
column7: This idiom can form the noun showoff for the first definition.
column8: Elizabeth is an excellent swimmer, but I don't like the way she shows off in front of everyone. It's very obvious that she enjoys being a showoff. Jacquie showed her large wedding ring off to all her friends.

column6: to become familiar with routine procedures at work or school
column8: The job applicant didn't have much previous experience or knowledge, but she seemed intelligent enough to learn the ropes quickly. It took the new schoolteacher a year to learn the ropes regarding administrative and curricular matters.

column6: to hope to have good results, to hope that nothing bad will happen
column7: This idiom reflects the way people cross their fingers to hope for good luck.
column8: Let's keep our fingers crossed that we got passing grades on that college entrance exam. Jerry kept his fingers crossed that the good weather would hold up for the picnic he was planning for the coming weekend.

column6: to recover safely from an unpleasant or dangerous situation
column8: After a series of personal and professional difficulties, it's amazing that George has landed on his feet so quickly. Some young adults get into so much trouble at school that they are never able to land on their feet again. They drop out before graduating.

column6: to distribute in large quantity (S); to speak of others in a critical manner (S)
column8: Mary's mom dished out two or three scoops of ice cream for each child at the birthday party. Larry can't seem to take any criticism of his actions but he certainly likes to dish it out.

column6: to communicate with, to make someone understand (also: to break through to)
column7: This idiom has the meaning of to make someone "catch on" (Lesson 29, eighth idiom, the first definition)
column8: Some of the students in my reading class understand English so poorly that it is difficult to get through to them. The doctors have never succeeded in breaking through to Mr. Ames, who is a silent and secretive patient.

column6: to fulfill a promise, to be responsible
column7: An idiom with the opposite meaning is to break one's word.
column8: Suzanne kept her word to me not to let on to others that I intend to step down next month. Thomas always intends to keep his word, but invariably the end result is that he breaks his word. He just isn't capable of being a responsible person.

column6: to be very busy, to have too much to do (also: to be up to one's ears); to be beyond one's ability to understand
column8: I'd love to take a week off for a hiking trip, but at the moment I am over my head in work. Maybe next week when I'm only up to my ears! It was impossible for the tutor to get through to Bill about the physics problem because the subject matter was over Bill's head.

column6: to deserve, to receive a just punishment (also: to bring upon)
column8: If you drink alcohol and then drive a car, you're only asking for trouble. Don't complain about your cut in salary. You asked for it by refusing to heed our repeated warnings not to be late and inefficient.

column5: to be a far cry from
column6: to be very different from
column8: I enjoyed visiting Seattle, but it was a far cry from the ideal vacation spot I expected. Ned is enjoying his new job, but his responsibilities are a far cry from what he was told they would be.

column6: certainly, definitely, naturally (also: of course); using any possible way or method
column8: If the Johnsons invite us for dinner, then by all means we have to return the invitation. Of course, we don't have to invite their children, too. In order to ensure its survival, the ailing company has to obtain an infusion of cash by all means.

column6: to restore one's financial security, to resolve a difficult financial obligation
column8: After years of struggling to get ahead, the young couple finally got out from under their debts. The ailing company, succeeding in obtaining the necessary cash, was able to get out from under its financial burdens.

column5: to take the bull by the horns
column6: to handle a difficult situation with determination
column7: This idiom is usually used when someone has been postponing an action for some time and finally wants or needs to resolve it.
column8: After three years of faithful service, Jake decided to take the bull by the horns and ask his boss for a raise. Vic has been engaged to Laura for a long time now, and I know that he loves her. He should take the bull by the horns and ask her to marry him.

column6: to assist, to aid, to help (also: to lend someone a hand) (S)
column8: Would you give me a hand lifting this heavy box? When Terry's car broke down at night on the highway, no one would stop to lend her a hand.

column6: to clap one's hands in applause, to applaud (S)
column8: After the talented new vocalist had sung her number, the audience gave her a big hand. Should we give a big hand to each beauty contestant is as she is introduced, or should we wait until all the introductions are finished?

column6: to waste time, to be idle
column8: Some of the workers in our office always goof off when the boss is out. On Saturday afternoons, I like to go to a movie or just goof off at home.

column6: to answer in a rude manner, to speak disrespectfully
column8: Billy, if you talk back to me like that once more, you're going to spend the rest of the day in your room. The school principal had to reprimand the child for talking back to her teacher.

column6: to be popular or fashionable; to be available at one's work or home
column8: Most young people tend to want anything that is in at the time, but a few don't care about current trends. Could you please tell me when Mrs. Zachary will be in? I'd like to talk to her soon.

column6: to be unpopular or no longer in fashion; to be away from one's work or home
column8: These days, designer jeans are in and long skirts are out. I'm sorry, Mr. Jensen is out at the moment. Could I take a message?

column6: to determine to be unacceptable, to refuse to consider
column8: I don't mind helping him with his homework, but I draw the line at writing a term paper for him. The conference organizers tried to accommodate the needs of the various interest groups, but they drew the line at extending the conference by two days.

column6: to disobey or ignore normal procedures or rules (also: to step out of line)
column8: When a child gets out of line in that teacher's class, she uses the old-fashioned method of making the child sit in the corner of the room. Any employee who steps out of line by coming to work in an unacceptable condition will be fired.

column6: rehearsal, practice session
column8: The college president requested a dry run of the graduation ceremony in order to ensure that all aspects went smoothly. Before the manager presented the reorganizational plans to the board of directors, he did several dry runs of his presentation.

column6: to play music that one has heard but never read (S); to proceed without plan, to do spontaneously (S)
column7: The pronoun it is often used with the second definition.
column8: That pianist can play most popular music by ear. She never needs to read sheet music. My husband wanted to plan our trip carefully, but I argued that it was more fun if we played it by ear.

column6: to be in another person's position, to face the same situation as another person
column8: If I were in your shoes, I wouldn't take too many classes this semester. When his boss finds out about that accounting error, I wouldn't want to be in his shoes.

column6: to remind constantly, to nag
column8: Lynn always has to keep after her children about cleaning up their rooms and doing chores around the house. Lon is so forgetful that it's necessary to keep after him about every little thing.

column6: to repair or put back in good condition (S); to arrange a date or an engagement for another person (S)
column8: Instead of buying an expensive new home, we decided to buy an older home and fix it up ourselves. Since my visiting friend didn't have a date for dinner, I fixed her up with a male friend of mine. They got along very well together.

column6: to be victimized or cheated
column8: When the jeweler confirmed that the diamonds that the woman had purchased abroad were really fake, she exclaimed, "I've been had!" The angry customer complained about being overcharged at the store, asserting that this was the third time that he had been had.
